column1: • The transport properties of nonlinear non-equilibrium dynamical systems, particularly ratchet systems, are not well understood.

column2: • Ratchet systems are asymmetric periodic potentials where an ensemble of particles experience directed transport.
• The interest in ratchet systems lies in the possibility of extracting useful work from unbiased noisy fluctuations, as seen in biological systems.

column1: • Recent studies have focused on the behavior of deterministic chaotic ratchets and Hamiltonian ratchets.

column2: • Chaotic systems are defined by their sensitive dependence on initial conditions, and their behavior is generally complex and dependent on system parameters.

column1: • A few years ago, Mateos considered a specific ratchet model with a periodically forced underdamped particle.

column2: • He showed that the current, defined as the time-averaged velocity of an ensemble of particles, could be either positive or negative depending on the amplitude of the periodic forcing.
• He conjectured a connection between current direction reversal and bifurcations from chaotic to periodic behavior in trajectory dynamics.

column1: • Later, Barbi and Salerno argued that Mateos' conjecture was not valid even in the specific system considered.

column2: • They presented results showing that current reversals could occur in the absence of bifurcations from periodic to chaotic behavior.
• They proposed an alternative origin for current reversal, related to the stability properties of rotating periodic orbits.

column1: • The authors of the current paper investigate the impact of different ensembles of particles on the current in a chaotic deterministic ratchet.

column2: • They show that the current depends significantly on the details of the initial ensemble and that it is important to discard transients in quantifying the current.

column1: • The authors then discuss the connection between the bifurcation diagram for individual particles and the behavior of the current.

column2: • They find that while they disagree with many of the details of Barbi and Salerno's results, the broader conclusion still holds: it is possible to have current reversals in the absence of bifurcations from chaos to periodic behavior, as well as bifurcations without any accompanying current reversals.

column1: • The authors propose a generalized version of Mateos' conjecture: bifurcations for trajectory dynamics as a function of system parameter are associated with abrupt changes in the current.

column2: • Depending on the specific value of the current, these abrupt changes may lead to a net current reversal, but not necessarily so.

column2: + * Known for planar property and mutual focusing, colliding plane waves (CPW) result in spacelike singularities.

column3: - * These singularities are weakened when waves are endowed with relative cross polarization.
- * A solution by Chandrasekhar and Xanthopoulos (CX) has a Cauchy horizon (CH) instead of a spacelike singularity.
- * Yurtsever showed that CH in CPW is unstable against plane-symmetric perturbations.

column2: + * A linear perturbation analysis by CX also shows an analogous result.

column3: - * Any perturbation applied to CPW turns CH into an essential singularity.
- * The electromagnetic (EM) field itself weakens the strength of singularity in CPW.
- * Collision of pure EM waves must have a special significance regarding singularity formation.

column2: + * The Bell-Szekeres (BS) solution describes the collision of two linearly polarized step EM waves.

column3: - * The singularity formed in the interaction region of BS is removable by a coordinate transformation.
- * On null boundaries, it possesses essential curvature singularities.
- * Cross polarization and EM field both play roles in the nature of resulting singularity.

column2: + * The cross-polarized version of BS (CPBS) solution was found long ago.

column3: - * This metric has the nice feature that Weyl scalars are all regular in the interaction region.
- * Cross polarization does not remove singularities formed on null boundaries.
- * The paper considers CPBS as a test ground with various added test fields to justify the validity of a CH stability conjecture.

column2: + * The conjecture suggests that for all maximally extended spacetimes with CH, the backreaction due to a field will affect the horizon in one of the following manners.

column3: - * If certain scalars are finite, the CH remains non-singular.
- * If certain scalars diverge, an nsc singularity will be formed at the CH.
- * If null dust density diverges, an sc singularity will be formed at the CH.

column2: + * The paper investigates the stability of quasiregular (QR) singularities in the incoming region of CPBS spacetime.

column3: - * Generic test fields are added to the background geometry to study their reaction.
- * The stability conjecture is used to predict the nature of singular",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column2: • Deep field surveys have reached exposures of 1 Ms, detecting normal galaxies at fluxes below 9 × 10^-15 erg cm^-2 s^-1 in the 0.5-2 keV band.
• Normal galaxies contribute up to 50% of the X-ray background (XRB) flux in the 0.5-2 keV band.
• The Chandra Deep Field-North (CDF-N) survey has detected many normal galaxies down to fluxes of 2 × 10^-17 erg cm^-2 s^-1, corresponding to a look-back time of 9 Gyr.
• The X-ray luminosity per unit B-band luminosity is expected to be larger at higher redshifts due to increased star formation rates.
• The study focuses on normal galaxies in the redshift range 0.52-1.0, using the CDF-N data.
• Galaxies were selected based on optical magnitude, morphology, and lack of X-ray detection within 40"".
• The sample was divided into redshift bins, and X-ray images were stacked for each bin.
• Significant detections were found in the soft band (0.5-2 keV) for all redshift bins up to z = 0.9.
• The average X-ray luminosity of galaxies increased by a factor of 1.6 from z = 0.52 to z = 0.9.
• Assuming an XRB flux density of 6.4 × 10^-12 erg cm^-2 s^-1 deg^-2, spiral galaxies not yet individually detected contribute 85% of the soft XRB.

column1: • Lower power dissipation due to spin toggling instead of charge movement.
• Immunity to noise as spin does not couple easily to stray electric fields.
• Potential for faster operation as limited by spin flip time rather than charge transit time.
• Proposed in 1994 using three spins in quantum dots.
• Utilizes exchange interaction and external magnetic field.
• Realizes a universal logic gate with a truth table identical to a NAND gate.
• Long-lived metastable states can cause incorrect outputs.
• High input bit rates are required to avoid this issue.
• Bidirectional exchange interaction can prevent unidirectional logic signal flow.
• Multi-phase clocking can enforce unidirectionality but has practical challenges.
• Spin coherence times are much larger than charge coherence times.
• Spin-based qubits can be used to realize universal quantum gates.
• Optical readout of spin states is more practical than electrical readout.
• **Cataclysmic Variables (CVs) and their Orbital Period Distribution**

column2: + • CVs are short-period binaries with a white dwarf (WD) primary and a low-mass main sequence secondary.
+ • The secondary fills its Roche lobe and transfers mass to the WD through the inner Lagrangian point.
+ • The orbital period distribution of CVs with hydrogen-rich donors lacks systems in the 2-3 hr period range (period gap) and has a sharp cut-off at around 77 minutes.
+ • Theoretical models have not been able to reproduce the precise position of the observed short-period cut-off and the shape of the CV orbital period distribution near this cut-off.
+ • Systems evolving under the influence of gravitational radiation (GR) as the only sink of orbital angular momentum reach a minimum period at around 65 minutes.

+ • The probability of finding a system within a given period range is proportional to the time taken to evolve through this region, leading to an accumulation of systems (a spike) at the minimum period.
+ • The observed distribution does not show this spike, suggesting that the minimum period is not caused by GR alone.
+ • The orbital period evolution reflects the radius evolution of the mass donor, governed by mass transfer and thermal relaxation.

column1: • **Investigating the Minimum Period and the Period Spike**

column2: + • The authors investigate ways to increase the period minimum by increasing the mass transfer rate and to ""hide"" the spike by introducing a spread of minimum periods in the CV population.
+ • They study the effect of a form of consequential angular momentum loss (CAML) where the angular momentum is lost as a consequence of the mass transferred from the secondary.
+ • The authors also consider the effect of tidal deformation of the secondary on the period minimum.
+ • They compare the observed short-period CV period distribution with various theoretically synthesized model distributions based on their calculations.

column2: • Broad emission lines like Hα provide insights into the structure and kinematics of gas near the central supermassive black hole.
• Two populations of Type 1 AGN are identified based on Hα line widths: Population A (FWHM Hα = 1000 - 4000 km/s) and Population B (FWHM Hα = 4000 - 12000 km/s).
• Fe II emission is almost ubiquitous in bright Type 1 quasars and correlates with Hα line width.
• Fe II emission is thought to arise in or near the emitting clouds that produce other low ionization lines.
• Narrow emission lines like [OIII]5007 are reliable measures of the local quasar rest frame, except for 'blue outliers' with weak [OIII] emission.
• Population A sources rarely show systematic red or blue shifts, while Population B sources show more complex line shift properties.
• A study (H08) claimed a systematic redshift of Fe II relative to [OIII]5007 and Hα in a majority of Type 1 quasars.
• The authors of the text tested this hypothesis using a sample of bright SDSS DR5 quasars and found no evidence for a systematic Fe II redshift.
• They conclude that low spectral signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) and strong He II emission in the H08 sample may have driven the conclusion of systematic Fe II redshifts.

• Entanglement can be transferred among bipartite partitions in a double Jaynes-Cummings model without decoherence, satisfying an identity at any time.
• In a system of two qubits interacting with two amplitude-damping reservoirs, the identity is still valid despite the presence of decoherence and non-equilibrium relaxation.
• Entanglement can be stably distributed among all bipartite subsystems if qubits and reservoirs can form bound states and non-Markovian effects are important.
• Entanglement sudden death (ESD) of qubits is not always accompanied by entanglement sudden birth (ESB) of reservoirs, contrary to previous findings.

column1: • **Origin of Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs) and Gravitational Waves (GWs)**

column2: • **GRBs** are powerful flashes of gamma-rays lasting from less than one second to tens of seconds, observed above the terrestrial atmosphere with x-ray and gamma-ray detectors aboard satellites.
• **GWs** are expected to be associated with GRBs, with a predicted duration of a few milliseconds and an amplitude of ~10^-21 at 1 Gpc.
• **Current Sensitivity** of GW detectors is not sufficient to detect GWs from a single GRB, but detection of a signal associated with the sum of many events is more realistic.
• **Search for Correlation** between GRBs and GW signals was conducted using an algorithm based on cross-correlating the outputs of two GW detectors, Explorer and Nautilus.
• **Bayesian Approach** was used to infer the GW amplitude consistent with the observation and to provide an upper limit on the GW amplitude.
• **Prior Probability Density Function** of GW burst intensities was considered, with a uniform distribution bounded to non-negative values.
• **Upper Limit** on the GW amplitude was determined to be ~10^-20 with 95% probability, with a time window of 100 ms.
• **Improved Upper Limit** was obtained with a time window of 1 s, improving the previous GW upper limit to about ~10^-21.
• **Previous Paper** by the same authors had given more stringent upper limits, but under the hypothesis that GW signals always occur at the same time with respect to the GRB arrival time.
• **Auriga/BATSE Result** estimated an upper limit of ~10^-21 with 95% confidence level, under the assumption that GWs arrive at the GRB time within a time window of 3 s.

• **Method** can be applied for any expected delay between GRBs and GWs, with appropriate time shifting of the integration window with respect to the GRB arrival time, according to the prediction of the chosen model.
• **Technical Assistance** was provided by several individuals and groups.
• **Contribution** was made by Dr. R. Elia.
• • Initial networks: @xmath1 and @xmath2 with no cross-links, each containing @xmath3 nodes.
• • Growth mechanism: Simultaneous addition of one node to each network at each time step.
• • Link attachment: New nodes attach links preferentially to existing nodes in both networks.
• **Model Analysis**
• • Rate equation approach: Used to analyze the time evolution of the joint distribution of intra- and cross-links in network @xmath1.
• • Power-law distributions: Obtained for total in-degree, intra-links, and cross-links in both networks.
• **Applications and Findings**
• • Citation networks: Intra-links represent citations within the same subject class, cross-links represent citations from other classes.
• • Human sexual contact networks: Intra-links represent homosexual interactions, cross-links represent heterosexual interactions.
• • Exponents of power-law distributions: Vary with coupling parameters, representing the rates of intra- and cross-linking.

column1: • The theoretical description of hadron production at large transverse momentum involves a two-step process: hard scattering of partons followed by fragmentation to hadrons.
• The first step is calculable in perturbative QCD, while the second step uses fragmentation functions determined phenomenologically.
• The fragmentation process is found to be inadequate for intermediate transverse momentum in heavy-ion collisions, where recombination of partons is more appropriate.
• The purpose of this paper is to introduce the notion of shower partons and determine their distributions to represent fragmentation functions in terms of recombination.
• The shower parton distributions (SPDs) are determined from fragmentation functions using a fitting procedure and are shown to reproduce the fragmentation functions well.

column2: + • Optimization problem with nonconvex matrix-valued mapping inequality constraints
+ • Applications in static output feedback controller design and topology optimization
+ • Previous methods: augmented Lagrangian functions, generalized sequential semidefinite programming, alternating directions, convex-concave decomposition
+ • Approximate feasible set of nonconvex problem by sequence of inner positive semidefinite convex approximation sets
+ • Generalization of inner convex approximation method from scalar optimization to nonlinear semidefinite programming
+ • Regularization technique to ensure strict descent

+ • Fireshell theory describes the evolution of a baryon-loaded pair plasma in a relativistic context.
+ • Dyadotorus concept is a specific configuration of an optically thick, baryon-loaded pair plasma around a Kerr-Newman black hole (BH).
+ • GRBs can be subdivided into various classes and subclasses, each with specific progenitors and astrophysical processes.
+ • Short GRBs (s-GRBs) are a new family of GRBs originating from binary neutron star (NS) mergers, with a prolonged GeV emission indicating BH formation.
+ • GRB 090510 is a prototype s-GRB, with a spectroscopically determined redshift and a well-observed GeV emission.

+ • Its analysis within the fireshell theory reveals a precise sequence of events, including a new structure in the thermal emission of the prompt GRB (p-GRB), the onset of the GeV emission linked to BH formation, and the derivation of the circumburst medium structure from the spiky structure of the prompt emission.

column1: * **Renormalization of the Standard Model (SM) at One Loop:**

column2: + The SM has three fundamental parameters in the gauge sector: the gauge coupling constants, the vacuum expectation value (vev) of the Higgs boson, and the muon decay constant.
+ The SM tree-level relation between the W and Z boson masses is not satisfied at one loop, and the SM is renormalized at one loop using the on-shell scheme.
+ The SM predicts the W boson mass quadratically as a function of the top quark mass.
+ The model has four fundamental parameters in the gauge sector: the additional parameter is the vev of the real scalar triplet.
+ The model is renormalized using the effective leptonic mixing angle as the fourth input parameter.
+ The model predicts the W boson mass logarithmically as a function of the top quark mass.
+ The model has five fundamental parameters in the gauge sector: the heavy gauge boson masses and the vev of the bi-doublet and triplet Higgs bosons.
+ The model is renormalized using the effective weak mixing angle as the fourth input parameter.
+ The model predicts the W boson mass logarithmically as a function of the top quark mass, suppressed by the heavy gauge boson masses.
+ • A log-Riemann surface is a riemann surface with a local holomorphic diffeomorphism to the complex plane, such that the added points in the metric completion are discrete.
+ • A log-Riemann surface of finite type has finitely many ramification points and a finitely generated fundamental group.

+ • An exp-algebraic curve is an equivalence class of log-Riemann surface structures of finite type, given by a punctured compact riemann surface and equivalence classes of germs of meromorphic functions with poles at the punctures.
+ • A log-Riemann surface of finite type is given by a punctured compact riemann surface and a meromorphic function with exponential singularities at the punctures.
+ • The uniformization theorems give germs of meromorphic functions at the punctures with poles of specific orders, determining the log-Riemann surface.
+ • Spaces of functions and 1-forms with exponential singularities are defined on a log-Riemann surface of finite type.
+ • Integrals of 1-forms along curves joining infinite ramification points converge, giving a pairing with cohomology.
+ • Two exp-algebraic curves with the same underlying riemann surface, punctures, and isomorphic line bundles with the same induced isomorphism are isomorphic.
+ • The theorem is proven using approximation and exactness results.

column1: • The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems on crystal lattices, which are a generalization of classical lattice structures.

column2: • Crystal lattices have periodic global structures but inhomogeneous local structures.
• The paper constructs a scaling limit of a crystal lattice using discrete harmonic maps.
• The paper formulates the symmetric simple exclusion process and the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process on crystal lattices.
• The main theorem states that the density of particles converges to a solution of a quasi-linear parabolic equation as the scaling limit.
• The paper introduces local function bundles and proves a replacement theorem, which allows for replacing local averages by global averages of the empirical density.
• The proof of the replacement theorem is based on the one-block estimate and the two-blocks estimate.
• The paper proves the one-block estimate and the two-blocks estimate using the local ergodic theorem.
• The paper derives the quasi-linear parabolic equation using the replacement theorem and completes the proof of the main theorem.
• The paper gives examples corresponding to ones in section [harmonic] and states the main theorem for each example.

column1: • **Charge Transfer between Organic and Inorganic Components**

column2: • • Challenging task, especially in the single-molecule limit
• • Electron addition and removal energies change upon adsorption on a substrate due to image charge effect
• • Quasiparticle (qp) description is a common way to calculate these energies
• • Density functional theory (DFT) is often used to calculate energy levels, but has limitations and approximations
• • Alternative approach to calculate charge transfer energies
• • Avoids interpretative issues and is computationally efficient
• • Translates qp problem into an energy differences problem
• • Used to study benzene molecule adsorption on graphene in various configurations
• • Depend on molecule-to-substrate distance due to image charge formation
• • CDFT agrees well with experimental data and classical electrostatic model
• • Stone-Wales defect in graphene does not affect energy level alignment
• • Presence of other benzene molecules changes charge transfer energies
• • Describes interaction of point-like charge and uniform planar charge distribution
• • Takes into account finite dielectric constant of graphene
• • Agrees well with CDFT results for benzene on graphene
• • Different from perfect metal due to graphene's screening properties

column1: * **Critical Casimir Forces (CCFs) in a System of Two Colloids Near a Substrate:**

column2: + Studied the total and many-body contributions to normal and lateral CCFs acting on one colloid (2) in the presence of another colloid (1) and a substrate.
+ Found that the total normal CCF can change sign, leading to unstable mechanical equilibrium configurations.
+ Observed that colloids tend to aggregate laterally based on their boundary conditions (BCs).
+ Determined the pure many-body contribution to the force acting on colloid (2) by subtracting pairwise forces.
+ Found that the normal many-body CCF can change sign at fixed temperature upon varying the lateral position of colloid (2).
+ Compared results with quantum-electrodynamic Casimir interactions and van der Waals forces between atoms near a surface.
+ Investigated the many-body contribution to the normal CCF acting on colloid (1) when colloids are vertically aligned with respect to the substrate.
+ Found that the many-body contribution depends on the BCs of the colloids.
+ Observed that the contribution of the many-body CCF to the total force is between 10% and 15%.

column1: • The text discusses the relationship between galaxy properties and their environments using data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).

• Galaxy environment is independent of surface brightness and concentration at fixed color and luminosity.
• The study investigates the scale dependence of these relationships and finds that:
• The dependence of mean environment on color persists to the lowest luminosities explored.
• A stronger correlation amplitude implies a steeper correlation function slope.
• In regions of a given overdensity on small scales, the overdensity on large scales does not relate to recent star formation history.

column1: • **Optomechanical System Design**: The paper presents a new design for an optomechanical system consisting of a microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide.
• **Universality and Reactive Coupling**: This design is universal and enables the study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling.
• **Origin of Reactive Coupling**: The origin of reactive coupling lies in the mechanical motion dependence of the extrinsic losses of the disk resonator and phase-dependent gradient forces.

• **Cooling and Nonlinear Response**: While cooling is desirable for studying quantum effects, the paper focuses on investigating the nonlinear response of the microdisk resonator to pump-probe fields.
• **Normal Mode Splitting**: The paper reports reactive-coupling-induced normal mode splitting, which was not observed in previous works using only dispersive coupling.
• The text discusses the dynamics of a quantum many-body system out of equilibrium, focusing on magnetization transport in a one-dimensional quantum Ising chain.
• The system is initially prepared in a nonequilibrium state with inhomogeneity in transverse magnetization.
• The dynamics is studied in the presence of a homogeneous and constant external transverse field.
• The magnetization does not become homogeneous even after infinite time, due to the presence of odd-occupation basis states with zero energy.
• The magnetization exhibits oscillatory behavior with a power-law decay in the envelope, independent of the external field strength.
• The frequency of oscillation shows a non-analytic behavior at the critical point of the quantum phase transition.
• The final magnetization at each site also exhibits different behavior in the ordered and disordered phases.
• The initial configuration contains several parameters, and the observed dynamics is valid for arbitrary values of these parameters.
- • Occur in gapless 2sc and g2sc phases.
- • Meissner screening masses for five gluons become imaginary, indicating a type of chromomagnetic instability.
- • Calculations in gcfl phase show the same type of instability.
- • Instability is a property of gapless phases, with a few exceptions.
- • G2sc phase is also unstable with respect to an external neutral baryon current.
- • Paramagnetic response to an external vector current suggests a vector current can be spontaneously generated.
- **Neutral Baryon Current Generation and Loff State:**
- • Quasiparticles spontaneously obtain a superfluid velocity, breaking rotational symmetry.
- • Loff state can not cure the 8-th gluon's magnetic instability in charge neutral 2-flavor system.
- • Spontaneously generated nambu-goldstone currents can cover gluon phase and one-plane wave loff state.
- • Exists in charge neutral 2-flavor system, where both off-diagonal and 8-th gluons exhibit magnetic instability.
- • Mismatch is close to diquark gap, suggesting a spin-1 condensate might stabilize this window.

column2: • • Star clusters form in molecular clouds, with only a small percentage of gas turned into stars.
• • Gas expulsion occurs due to stellar winds and supernovae, causing rapid changes in the cluster's gravitational potential.
• • This process can leave clusters out of equilibrium, with significant mass loss and a tail of escaping stars.
• • Observations of three young massive clusters (M82-F, NGC 1569-A, NGC 1705-1) show excess light at large radii.
• • Simulations of gas expulsion from star clusters reproduce these observations, confirming that the clusters are not in dynamical equilibrium.
• • The simulations suggest that the clusters have effective star formation efficiencies of around 40-50%.
• • Clusters with low effective star formation efficiencies (<30%) can dissolve rapidly, contributing to infant mortality.
• • Gas expulsion can significantly lower the stellar mass of a cluster, affecting the observed mass function.
• • Future work will explore the dynamical state of young clusters to constrain star formation efficiencies and account for infant weight-loss.

column2: + * Quantum fluctuations of electric and magnetic fields give rise to zero-point energy.
+ * Casimir predicted that two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum should attract each other with a force inversely proportional to the fourth power of separation.
+ * Lifshitz, Dzyaloshinskii, and Pitaevskii generalized Casimir's theory to isotropic dielectrics.
+ * The force between two uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions can be derived according to an analytical formula.
+ * At very short distances, the theory provides a complete description of the non-retarded van der Waals force.
+ * At larger separations, retardation effects give rise to a long-range interaction.
+ * Lifshitz's equation also shows that two plates made out of the same material always attract, regardless of the choice of the intervening medium.
+ * For slabs of different materials, the sign of the force depends on the dielectric properties of the medium in which they are immersed.

column1: * **Parsegian and Weiss's Work on Anisotropic Materials**

column2: + * Parsegian and Weiss derived an equation for the non-retarded van der Waals interaction energy between two dielectrically anisotropic plates immersed in a third anisotropic material.
+ * The torque between two parallel birefringent slabs causes them to spontaneously rotate towards the configuration in which their principal axes are aligned.
+ * The anisotropy of the zero-point energy between the plates generates the torque that makes them rotate towards configurations of smaller energy.
+ * The casimir-lifshitz force between isotropic dielectrics has been receiving considerable attention in the modern literature.
+ * The authors calculate the magnitude of the torque induced by quantum fluctuations for specific materials and discuss possible experimental validations of the effect.
+ * They consider a small birefringent disk made out of quartz or calcite placed parallel to a birefringent barium titanate (BTO) plate in vacuum.
+ * The magnitude of the torque is within the sensitivity of available instrumentation, provided that the plate and the disk are kept at sub-micron distances.
+ * At such short separations, the tendency of the two surfaces to stick together represents a major technical difficulty.
+ * The measurement of the rotation of the disk may seem to be an extremely challenging problem, which",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: * **Adaptive Mode Selection and Power Allocation for Bidirectional Relay Networks**

column2: + **Objective**: Maximize sum rate of users in a bidirectional relay network with fading links and a joint power budget.
+ **Protocol**:

column3: - Selects optimal transmission mode from six possible modes.
- Allocates optimal powers to transmitting nodes based on instantaneous CSI and long-term statistics.

column2: + **Assumptions**:

column3: - Users always have enough information to send.
- Number of time slots satisfies a certain condition.

column2: + **Formulation**: Optimization problem with constraints for sum rate maximization, total transmit power, power non-negativity, mode selection, and time sharing.
+ **Solution**: Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions lead to a unique optimal solution.
+ **Mode Selection**: Metric based on instantaneous capacity and allocated power with thresholds.
+ **Power Allocation**: Optimal powers derived for each mode based on KKT conditions.
+ **Simulation Results**:

column3: - Proposed protocol outperforms existing protocols in terms of average sum rate.
- Optimal power allocation crucial for low total power budget.

column2: + **Delay Analysis**: Average delay can be bounded with modifications to the optimal protocol.

column1: • The acoustic oscillations imprinted in the matter power spectrum at recombination serve as a standard ruler for cosmological measurements.

column2: • These oscillations can be accurately calculated based on measurements of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropy power spectrum.
• The interpretation of these oscillations at low redshifts is robust, even if the CMB measurements are affected by new physics, such as undetected relativistic particles.
• The baryon-to-photon ratio and the epoch of matter-radiation equality, which are robustly measured in the CMB, are crucial for this robustness.
• The actual densities of matter and radiation drop out of the calculation, and only their ratio matters.
• The acoustic peak method depends on measuring the sound horizon, which is the comoving distance that a sound wave can travel between the end of inflation and the epoch of recombination.
• The sound horizon depends only on the baryon-to-photon ratio and the redshift of equality, making it a reliable standard ruler for constraining cosmology.
• Recent excitement in neutrino physics due to new experiments indicating oscillations.
• Solar and atmospheric neutrino experiments provide independent evidence for oscillations.
• Accelerator and reactor experiments provide strict bounds on neutrino oscillation parameters.
• LSND experiment reported evidence for μ → e oscillations.
• Proposed ansatz for 3-generation neutrino mass matrix: M_ν = diag(m_1, m_2, m_3) with m_1 = m_2.
• Motivated by SO(10) grand unified model and seesaw mechanism.
• Assumes first term in seesaw formula dominates.
• Leads to specific predictions for neutrino masses and mixing angles.
• Can be combined with experimental results to infer neutrino mass matrix texture.
• Allows for reconstruction of underlying neutrino mass matrix.
• Used preliminary analysis of all neutrino experiments by Ohlsson and Snellman.
• Best fit for squared mass differences and lepton mixing matrix found.
• Two essentially different solutions found: type I and type II.
• Non-observation of neutrinoless double beta decay provides constraint on neutrino masses.
• Predictions for type I and type II solutions found to be acceptable.
• Reconstructed underlying neutrino mass matrices for each case.

column2: + • Matter (Ordinary Matter): 4% of total mass-energy, consists of baryonic matter.
+ • Dark Matter: 23% of total mass-energy, non-baryonic, unknown nature.
+ • Dark Energy: 73% of total mass-energy, mysterious, possibly a cosmological constant.
+ • Ordinary Matter: Visible, luminous, consists of galaxies, gas, etc.
+ • Dark Matter: Non-luminous, dominates mass in galaxies, forms halos around galaxies.
+ • Dark Energy: Causes accelerated expansion of the universe.
+ • Cold Dark Matter (CDM): Non-relativistic at galaxy formation, associated with WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles).
+ • Neutralinos: Superpartner of Higgs boson in supersymmetric models.
+ • Kaluza-Klein States: Predicted in theories with extra dimensions.
+ • Central Density Profile: Predicts a central peak, while observations suggest a constant density core.
+ • Satellite Galaxies: Predicts too many satellite galaxies around large galaxies.
+ • Tully-Fisher Relation: Not naturally explained by CDM.
+ • Explains rotation curves of galaxies without dark matter.
+ • Modifies Newton's laws in weak gravitational fields.
+ • Successful in explaining observations, but not yet understood within the framework of fundamental physics.

column1: * **Phase Diagram of Quenched Polymers with Long-Range Interactions:**

column2: + In 3D, pas behave similarly to random chains with short-range interactions for small excess charge, and spatial conformations strongly depend on excess charge for larger values.
+ In every space dimension, there is a critical charge such that pas with excess charge cannot form a compact state.
+ The probability of a randomly charged pa having such an excess charge depends on both the space dimension and its length.
+ The borderline case of 3D provides valuable insight into the behavior of the system in general space dimensions.
+ The ground state energy of a pa can be determined accurately by specifying its net charge.
+ The ground state energy of alternating polymers is only smaller by about 16% than the mean condensation energy of unrestricted sequences.
+ The dependence of the quench-averaged ground state energies on the length of the chain scales as expected from the energy definition.
+ The density of states for different excess charges is shifted with respect to each other.
+ Almost all pas have a unique ground state, and the gaps to the second lowest energy states remain of order of the energy discretization.
+ The heat capacity of pas with zero excess charge vanishes in the low-temperature limit.
+ The heat capacity of random pas with zero excess charge also has a peak, which may represent a crossover or a glass transition.

column1: * **Contour Plots of Energy vs. Radius of Gyration:**

column2: + The contour plots show that the lowest energy configurations are very different for different excess charges.
+ The lowest energy contour of the chain with excess charge slightly smaller than the critical value is almost horizontal, indicating that the chain will not collapse upon lowering temperature.
+ The radius of gyration of the unrestricted ensemble of quenches scales differently from the sub-ensembles of fixed excess charge.
+ The ground states of annealed pas correspond to a uniform distribution of excess charge along the backbone.
+ The energies per atom of the ground states of annealed pas are consistent with the known values of the condensation energy and surface tension.

column1: • **Electronic and Magnetic Properties of CrX and CrAsX Alloys**

column2: + Calculated for lattice parameters varying between 5.45 and 6.6
+ Half-metallic character maintained over a wide range of lattice parameters
+ Exchange interactions and Curie temperatures calculated
+ Ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic interactions present
+ Strongest interactions between Cr atoms and nearest empty spheres (es-1)
+ Exchange interactions between Cr atoms and other atoms (X) also significant
+ Calculated using mean-field approximation (MFA) and random-phase approximation (RPA)
+ Curie temperatures vary with lattice parameter and alloy composition
+ Pnictides have higher Curie temperatures than chalcogenides
+ Local moments on Cr atoms and induced moments on other sublattices
+ Induced moments on empty spheres (es-1 and es-2) are smaller than on other sublattices
+ Maximum ratio between induced moment on X and moment on Cr is 0.18 for CrAs and 0.15 for CrSb
+ Achieved for lattice parameters above critical values
+ Critical values vary with alloy composition
+ Half-metallic gap larger in chalcogenides than in pnictides

column1: • **Exchange Interactions and Curie Temperatures for CrX (X = S, Se, Te)**

column2: + Calculated for mixed alloys CrAsX (X = Sb, S, Se, Te)
+ Curie temperatures vary with lattice parameter and alloy composition
+ Mixed alloys have higher Curie temperatures than isoelectronic alloys (CrAs, CrSb, CrAsSb)
+ Epitaxial instability against nias structure for some compounds
+ zb CrSe stable only for lattice constants higher than 6.2
+ zb CrS antiferromagnetic at equilibrium lattice parameter
+ Ferromagnetic for CrAs and CrSb at all lattice parameters
+ Antiferromagnetic or complex magnetic structure for CrS, CrSe, and CrTe at low lattice parameters
+ Mixed alloys CrAsX (X = S, Se, Te) ferromagnetic at all lattice parameters

column1: - Transition layers exist due to thermal instability, allowing gas to coexist at different phases with large temperature gradients.
- An intermediate stable layer can exist between two transition layers, with a unique ionization parameter determined by steady-state conditions.
- The thickness of the intermediate layer is determined by hydrostatic equilibrium, and its optical depth is typically small.
- Recombination emission lines are dominant in photoionized plasmas, with radiative recombination followed by cascades as the main formation process.
- The emission equivalent width is independent of density and incident flux, depending only on the structure deduced from hydrostatic and energy balance equations.
- The strongest lines are hydrogen- and helium-like lines of oxygen, with equivalent widths approaching several tenths of an ev.
- Resonance line scattering can have significant optical depths, making reflection due to these lines important.
- The reflection equivalent width is a few tenths of an ev for strong resonance lines, similar to that of recombination emission lines.

- The appearance of reflected line spectra is different from that of recombination emission spectra, allowing for distinction between mechanisms with high-resolution spectroscopy.",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"

+ A graph is closed if it has a closed labeling.

column3: - A labeling is closed if it satisfies certain conditions.

column2: + A labeling is closed if it is complete and equal to an interval of the desired form.
+ A graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and narrow.

column3: - Chordal: No induced cycles of length 3 or less.
- Claw-free: No induced subgraph of the form K1,3.
- Narrow: Every vertex is distance at most one from every longest shortest path.

column2: + Algorithm labels the vertices of a connected graph.

column3: - Starts by labeling the vertex with the fewest number of edges connected to unlabeled vertices.
- Repeats the process for the remaining unlabeled vertices.

column2: + The labeling produced by the algorithm is closed if the input graph is chordal, claw-free, and narrow.

column3: - Base case: The first interval of the labeling is complete and equal to an interval of the desired form.
- Inductive step: If the labeling satisfies the conditions for all intervals up to i, then it also satisfies them for interval i+1.

column2: + A graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and its connected components are narrow.
+ The conditions of being chordal, claw-free, and narrow are independent.

column3: - Examples are given to illustrate this.

column2: + The 4-cycle is claw-free and narrow but not chordal.
+ A subsequent paper will explore further properties of closed graphs.
+ *Discovery and Spectrum:*

column3: - Discovered in early 20th century
- Continuum at all energies, highest energy particles known
- Power law energy spectrum, decreasing as cube of primary energy
- Extensive air showers for detection at high energies

column2: + *Composition and Origin:*

column3: - Uncertain composition at ultra-high energies
- Possible acceleration in astrophysical objects or decay of heavier particles
- No clear evidence for anisotropy or GZK cutoff
- New experiments planned to improve understanding

column2: + *Development and Detection:*

column3: - Multiple particle production in high-energy interactions
- Shower maximum at couple of thousand meters for vertical showers
- Most detectors oriented for vertical incidence

column2: + *Inclined Showers:*

column3: - Absorbed before reaching ground, but muons travel unattenuated
- Muon density patterns affected by Earth's magnetic field
- Useful for studying cosmic ray background to neutrino-induced showers
- Potential for primary composition study when combined with vertical measurements

* **X-ray Source XB158 in M31 Globular Cluster B158**

column2: + * Discovery and Periodicity

column3: - Discovered by Einstein Observatory
- Exhibits 10.017 s periodicity in X-ray intensity
- Orbital period likely around 10.017 s

column2: + * Nature of the System**

column3: - Probable low mass X-ray binary (LMXB) with a neutron star accretor
- Low mass donor star with separation ~10^6 cm

column2: + * Disk Precession and Superhumps**

column3: - Disk precession observed, causing dips in X-ray intensity
- Superhumps associated with the 3:1 resonance with the secondary
- Superhump period slightly longer than the orbital period

column2: + * X-ray Spectrum and Luminosity**

column3: - Blackbody + power law model fits the X-ray spectrum
- Photon index of 2.0, consistent with a neutron star accretor
- Luminosity varies between 1.5-2.5 x 10^37 erg s^-1

column2: + * Swift Observations and Super-Orbital Period**

column3: - 30 Swift observations over 2013 February 8 - March 9
- 0.310 keV luminosity varied by a factor of 15
- Super-orbital period of 5.65 ± 0.05 days detected

column2: + * Implications and Future Work**

column3: - Super-orbital period longer than predicted by 3D SPH simulations
- Lower mass ratio between donor and accretor likely
- Further study needed to confirm the nature of the donor star

column1: * **Methods for calculating resonance energies and lifetimes:**

column2: + *Complex scaling method:* Rotates the continuum part of the spectrum beyond the resonance's complex eigenvalue.
+ *Complex absorbing potential method:* Produces nonphysical complex energy stabilized points that must be removed.
+ *Real variational methods:* Reduces the problem to calculating eigenvalues of real symmetric matrices but has convergence issues.
+ *Pros:* Simple, both energy and width can be obtained as fitting parameters.
+ *Cons:* No clear procedure to assess accuracy or choose the best values, and convergence properties are unclear.
+ *Used by Pont et al. to analyze DOS properties.*
+ *Resonance energy and lifetime obtained using scaling properties of DOS.*
+ *Dependent on known lifetime values.*

column1: * **Recipe for selecting resonance energies and lifetimes:**

column2: + *Choose basis set size and non-linear parameter.*
+ *Select eigenvalues based on ordering and reverse inequalities.*
+ *Use finite size scaling arguments to extrapolate data.*
+ *Resonance energy calculated using complex scaling method.*
+ *DOS method provides accurate but unstable results for large basis set sizes.*
+ *Bundle of states linked by crossings shows better convergence.*
+ *Resonance energy obtained from bundles of states.*
+ *Width calculated using DOS method converges to complex scaling value.*
+ *Energy converges linearly with basis set size for small width resonances.*
+ *Lifetime calculation more subtle, projection method gives discrete sets of values.*
+ *Best estimation obtained from extrapolation of linearly scaling set.*

• • The binary system consists of a 0.80 white dwarf and a 0.18 main-sequence companion star.

• • It is orbited by two planets: a 5.7 Earth-mass planet in a 0.04 AU orbit with an eccentricity of 0.26, and a more massive (7.6 Earth-mass) planet in a wider (0.12 AU) and more eccentric (0.42) orbit.
• • The two-planet configuration is dynamically unstable on a 100,000-year timescale.
• • However, a small fraction of numerical simulations exhibit long-term dynamical stability.
• • The original binary likely lost more than half its mass during the common-envelope phase, reducing the binary separation by more than an order of magnitude.
• • Planets could have survived this phase and migrated to their current orbits due to the mass loss.
• • The presence of the inner planet allows for breaking the degeneracy between the donor mass at the moment of Roche-lobe overflow, its radius, and the mass of its core.
• • The outer planet validates this calculation and determines the conditions under which the CV was born.

column1: • The NCSM/RGM approach, combining microscopic cluster techniques with realistic interactions, has been extended to treat three-body cluster systems.
• This extension allows for the study of nuclear systems with three-body cluster structures, such as two-nucleon halo nuclei, resonant systems, and transfer reactions.
• The method was applied to study the ground state and continuum states of helium-11 (^{11}He) within a ^{10}He+n+n basis.
• The ground state energy of ^{11}He was calculated and compared to NCSM results, showing good agreement.
• The wave functions obtained feature an appropriate asymptotic behavior, unlike bound-state methods like NCSM.
• Preliminary results for low-energy phase shifts in different channels were obtained, including the known ^{11}He resonant state and a second low-lying resonance.
• Computing support for this work came from various sources, including LLNL, DOE/SC/NP, NERC, and TRIUMF.
• **Growth and Characterization of MnGe Thin Films on Si Substrates**

column2: + • **Preparation Method**

column3: - Used p-doped Si(111) substrates with resistivity between 1 and 10 Ωcm
- Heated substrates to 1100°C under UHV to remove oxide layer and achieve clean, flat surface
- Deposited 5 nm Mn layer, heated to 300°C to form MnSi seedlayer
- Codeposited Mn and Ge to grow MnGe thin films at 250°C with a rate of 0.15 Å/s

column2: + • **Structural Characterization**

column3: - RHEED patterns indicated two-dimensional film growth and b20 crystal structure
- AFM images showed Vollmer-Weber type island growth
- XRD measurements confirmed b20 crystal structure and lattice parameter of 4.750 Å, 1% smaller than bulk MnGe due to compressive strain

column2: + • **Magnetic Characterization**

column3: - Magnetic susceptibility measurements showed ordering temperature of 200 K, higher than bulk MnGe
- Magnetization measurements revealed saturation at around 1 T and magnetic moment per Mn atom half of bulk value
- Magnetoresistivity measurements showed negative MR effect with no remarkable features up to 5 T

column2: + • **Comparison with MnSi**

column3: - MnGe has shorter, more rigid helix and stronger Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction
- MnGe shows antiferromagnetic behavior, while MnSi shows ferromagnetic behavior at low temperatures
- MnGe has higher ordering temperature and smaller magnetoresistivity compared to MnSi

column2: + • **Definition**: The core entropy of a polynomial is a measure of its dynamical complexity, defined using the concept of a 'hubbard tree'.
+ • **Properties**:

column3: - • **Monotonicity**: The core entropy function is monotone along certain paths in the parameter space.
- • **Continuity**: The core entropy function is continuous at all angles, except possibly at purely periodic angles.
- • **Relation to Hausdorff Dimension**: The core entropy equals, up to a constant factor, the Hausdorff dimension of the set of biaccessible angles for the polynomial.
- • **Rational External Angles**: The core entropy of a polynomial with a rational external angle equals the asymptotic stretch factor of the polynomial as a rational map.

column2: + • **Computation**: Thurston's algorithm computes the core entropy of a polynomial with a rational external angle by constructing a matrix and finding its largest real eigenvalue.
+ • **Extension**: The algorithm can be extended to compute the core entropy for any angle, using an infinite version of the matrix and the concept of a 'spectral determinant'.
+ • **Continuity**: The extended algorithm proves the continuity of the core entropy function at all angles, including purely periodic angles.
+ • **Monotonicity**: The extended algorithm also proves the monotonicity of the core entropy function along all veins in the Mandelbrot set.",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: • GRBs are distant, highly energetic explosions in the universe.
• They are detected by their emission of gamma rays.
• The detection of x-ray, optical, and radio afterglows from some well-localized GRBs confirms their cosmological origin.
• The fireball model is strongly favored to explain GRBs.
• It is not known whether GRBs are due to highly collimated jets or isotropic fireballs.
• The energetics involved cannot be determined definitively without knowing the degree of beaming.
• Three methods have been proposed to determine the degree of beaming in GRBs:
• Analytic solutions suggest that optical afterglows from a jetted GRB should have a break in the light curve during the relativistic phase.
• Gruzinov argued that optical afterglows from a jet can be strongly polarized, up to tens of percents.
• The third method involves the detection of orphan afterglows, which are not associated with any detectable GRBs.
• Orphan afterglows can be produced by both jetted GRBs and isotropic fireballs (FGRBs) with initial Lorentz factor much less than one hundred.
• FGRBs can be observed in x-ray bands in the initial bursting phase, not in gamma-ray bands.
• Some anomalous events, such as fast x-ray transients and x-ray-rich GRBs, may be FGRBs.
• The detection of orphan afterglows does not necessarily mean that GRBs are highly collimated.
• To make use of information from orphan afterglow surveys correctly, it is necessary to know how to discriminate a jetted GRB orphan and an FGRB one.
• Long duration and faint in X-rays
• Featureless X-ray spectrum, no significant absorption
• X-ray source detected in error box
• Power-law spectrum typical of GRB afterglows
• Alternative identification as a background quasar unlikely

column2: + *Layered organic material AI3 studied since the 1980s
+ *Reveals low-energy massless Dirac fermions under high pressure (~2 GPa)
+ *Differences from graphene: tilted Dirac cones, anisotropy, smaller Fermi velocity, charge-ordered phase at ambient pressure
+ *Larger effective coupling constant for electron-electron interactions
+ *Presence of additional massive carriers near the Fermi level
+ *Magneto-transport measurements on AI3 crystals under high pressure (>3 GPa)
+ *Existence of high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes
+ *Interplay between Dirac fermions and massive holes at low energy
+ *Mobilities hint at scattering mechanisms due to strongly screened interaction potentials or other short-range scatterers
+ *Temperature-dependent carrier densities and mobilities
+ *Thermopower measurements support the two-carrier scenario
+ *Coexistence of Dirac electrons, Dirac holes, and massive electrons
+ *No significant pressure dependence of the carrier density
+ *High mobility of Dirac carriers (~10^4 cm^2/Vs) and low mobility of massive carriers (~10^2 cm^2/Vs)
+ *Power-law temperature dependence of mobilities for both carrier types

column1: • **Spin Response in Superconducting State of Fe-Based Superconductors ( Febs )**:

column2: + • **Two Superconducting Gap Scales**: Unequal gaps on outer hole and inner hole/electron Fermi surfaces.

column3: - • **Spin Resonance Frequency**: Shifts to lower frequency, proportional to the indirect gap between hole and electron bands.
- • **Maximal Energy Scale**: Depends on the exact band structure and wave vector of the spin resonance.

column2: + • **Four-Band Model**: Simple model to describe spin response with unequal gaps.

column3: - • **Imaginary Part of Susceptibility**: Shows gradual increase in @xmath6 state and spin resonance peak in @xmath7 state.
- • **Spin Resonance Frequency**: Shifts to lower frequency in unequal gap case.

column2: + • **Five-Orbital Model**: More realistic model based on DFT band structure.

column3: - • **Energy Spectrum**: Shows two energy scales connected with hole and electron bands.
- • **Spin Resonance Peak**: Shifts to lower frequency due to indirect gap between hole and electron bands.

column2: + • **Inelastic Neutron Scattering ( INS )**: Peak frequency in BaFe<sub>1.84</sub>Co<sub>0.16</sub>As<sub>0.84</sub> is 3.5 meV, consistent with spin resonance.
+ • **Andreev Spectroscopy**: Gap sizes in BaFe<sub>1.1</sub>Co<sub>0.9</sub>As<sub>0.9</sub> are 9 meV ( larger gap ) and 4 meV ( smaller gap ).
+ • **ARPES**: Electron Fermi surfaces and inner hole sheet have larger gap, while outer hole Fermi surface has smaller gap.
+ Introduced a 2D generalization of the dual random dimer model (2D-DRDM) with correlated impurities.
+ Impurities modify hopping with nearest neighbors and cannot be first neighbors.
+ Resonance energy exists where impurities are transparent, independent of system dimensionality.
+ Ground state driven towards homogeneity by 2D-DRDM.
+ Non-monotonic behavior of condensate spatial delocalization and condensate fraction with disorder strength.
+ Enhancement of condensate fraction and coherence near resonance energy.

column1: • **Many-Body Inverse Participation Ratio and Density Distribution**

column1: • • Independent Set: A subset of vertices in a graph where no two vertices are adjacent.
• • Independence Number: The size of the largest independent set in a graph.
• • Maximum Independent Set Problem: Finding an independent set with the largest number of vertices in a given graph.
• • Defined by vertex set V and edge set E, where V = {v0, v1, ..., v(n-1)} ∪ {w0, w1, ..., w(k-1)} and E = {(vi, wi) | 0 ≤ i < n, 0 ≤ j < k, (i+j) mod n ≠ 0} ∪ {(wi, wj) | 0 ≤ i < j < k}.
• • Inner Subgraph: Induced subgraph on n vertices.
• • Outer Cycle: Induced subgraph on k vertices.
• • Twin Vertices and Spoke Edges: Vertices vi and wi are twins, and the edge (vi, wi) is a spoke.
• • Upper Bound for Even k: For even k, the independence number of a generalized Petersen graph is at most ⌊n/2⌋ + 2k/3.
• • Lower Bounds for Even k: For even k, the independence number of a generalized Petersen graph is at least ⌊n/2⌋ + 2k/3 - 1.
• • Exact Values for k = 4: For k = 4, the independence number of a generalized Petersen graph is n/2 + 2 for even n, and (n + 1)/2 + 1 for odd n.
• • Conjecture: For all n and k, the independence number of a generalized Petersen graph is at most n/2 + k/2.

• • Linear Time Algorithm: For fixed k, the independence number of a generalized Petersen graph can be found in linear time using dynamic programming on graphs with bounded treewidth.",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"

column2: + Proposed two schemes: Phase Locking and Phase to Polarization Conversion.
+ Phase Locking Scheme:

column3: - Uses phase locking technique.
- Intrinsically possesses basis-dependent flaw.
- Can cover relatively short distances.
- Basis-dependent flaw can be controlled by pulse intensities.
- 3 or 5 times improvement in phase modulation accuracy generates key.
- Precise intensity control enables key generation with current technologies.

column2: + Phase to Polarization Conversion Scheme:

column3: - Converts phase encoding BB84 pulses to polarization modes.
- Can cover much longer distances with perfect single-photon fidelity.
- Achievable distances drop significantly with fidelity degradation.
- Requires very high fidelity and accurate estimation of single-photon fidelity.
- Passive device state preparation may be promising.
- Standard decoy BB84 is more robust against phase modulation degradation.
- Fluctuation of laser intensity and center frequency to be analyzed in future.

column2: + Basis-dependent flaws can be avoided with very accurate state preparation.
+ Both MDIQKD and standard QKD require accurate state preparation.
+ Our work highlights the importance of accurate state preparation.
+ **Accretion vs Mergers:** Uncertainty remains about whether massive stars form via accretion or mergers.
+ **High-Resolution Observations:** Recent observations suggest an accretion formation scenario for massive stars.
+ **Methanol Masers:** Exclusively trace regions of massive star formation and are offset from HII regions.
+ **Mir Observations:** Reveal embedded sources inside the cores at mid-infrared wavelengths.
+ **Point Sources:** Multiple, close point sources found within the protoclusters.
+ **Maser Association:** Methanol masers are found closest to the brightest mid-infrared point source.
+ **Monte Carlo Simulations:** Difficult to generate observed mass distributions using standard IMF.
+ **Unseen Mass:** Requires high stellar mass already in the cluster or dispersed gas mass.
+ • **Dark Energy**: Explained by modified gravity theories, such as Lovelock and Gauss-Bonnet theories.
+ • **Curvature Invariants**: Added or replaced in Einstein-Hilbert action to modify gravity.
+ • **Ricci Scalar and Gauss-Bonnet Invariant**: First and second Lovelock scalars, respectively.
+ • **Coupling with Scalar Field or Generic Function**: Two approaches to discuss dynamics of Gauss-Bonnet invariant in 4D.
+ • **Curvature-Matter Coupling**: Introduced in Gauss-Bonnet gravity.
+ • **Noether Symmetry Approach**: Used to construct cosmologically viable models.
+ • **Reconstruction and Stability**: Important issues in cosmology.
+ • **Power-Law Solutions**: Reconstructed in modified gravity theories.
+ • **Reconstruction of Cosmological Models**: De Sitter universe, power-law solutions, phantom/non-phantom eras, and ΛCDM model in @xmath0 theory.
+ • **Stability Analysis**: Against linear homogeneous perturbations for de Sitter and power-law solutions.

column1: - • MFs are real solutions of the Dirac equation, proposed as neutrino models and predicted in condensed matter systems.
- - Obey non-Abelian statistics, important for decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing.
- - Topological superconductors are potential platforms for hosting MFs.
- - Various realistic platforms, such as topological insulators, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains, have been proposed to support MFs.
- - Tunneling spectroscopy experiments show characteristic zero-bias peaks (ZBPs) as MF signatures.
- - However, ZBPs can also arise from other mechanisms, making MF identification challenging.
- - Alternative detection methods are necessary to obtain definitive MF signatures.
- • Coupled hybrid quantum dot (QD) - nanomechanical resonator (NR) system:
- - QD couples to nearby MF in iron chains on superconducting Pb surface via dipole-dipole interaction.
- - Optical pump-probe scheme detects MF signatures via coherent optical spectrum of the QD.
- - NR enhances exciton resonance spectrum, increasing MF detection sensitivity.
- - Coherent optical properties of QD show absorption and dissipation peaks at NR frequency and MF-induced signatures.
- - Electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) phenomenon observed under both coupled and uncoupled MF conditions.
- - QD-MF coupling strength can be determined by measuring peak splitting in probe absorption spectrum.
- - NR acting as a phonon cavity enhances MF detection sensitivity.

column2: + First evidence found in kaon system.
+ No other signal found yet.
+ Studying time reversal symmetry is a cornerstone for searching physics beyond the Standard Model.
+ Dynamical symmetry breaking, multi-Higgs models, spontaneous symmetry breaking, grand unified theories, extended gauge groups, super-symmetric theories, etc.
+ Each implies specific ways of time reversal violation.
+ Nuclear low-energy tests involve hadronic degrees of freedom (mesons and nucleons).
+ Effective odd nucleon-nucleon potentials or mesonic exchange potentials are introduced to extract hadronic degrees of freedom.
+ Quark models are used to relate quark degrees of freedom to hadronic degrees of freedom.
+ The constituent quark model, MIT bag model, and a relativistic model with linear confining potential are considered.

column1: * **Charge-2 Type Exchange and Axial Vector Type Exchange:**

column2: + Two basic contributions to effective one-boson exchange potentials: charge-2 type exchange and axial vector exchange.
+ Charge-2 type exchange is odd under time reversal symmetry and is only possible for charged boson exchange.
+ Axial vector type interaction is not restricted in isospin dependence.
+ Simplest operator for charge-2 type exchange: $\bar{q}_i \gamma_\mu \tau^a q_j$.
+ Operator for axial vector type exchange: $\bar{q}_i \gamma_\mu \gamma_5 \tau^a q_j$.
+ Matrix elements are evaluated using the Fock space representation of hadrons in terms of constituent quarks.
+ The Virginia potential is used to relate quark operators to effective hadronic operators.
+ Factors arising from quark structure effects reflect nucleon structure effects.
+ Origin of structure factors: spin, isospin structure, and different mass scales.
+ Factors relate the strength of odd coupling constants to the strength of even coupling constants.

column2: • Type 1 and Type 2 AGN differ due to angle-dependent circumnuclear obscuration by a dusty medium, or ""dust torus"".
• Dust absorbs UV/optical radiation and re-emits in the infrared.
• Type 1 AGN show more near-IR emission than Type 2 for the same intrinsic luminosity.
• This is consistent with the dust torus being seen face-on in Type 1 and edge-on in Type 2.
• The ratio of Type 1 to Type 2 AGN emission varies with wavelength.
• At 15μm, the ratio is ~1.4, indicating some anisotropy.
• A single cold dust screen cannot explain the observed anisotropy.
• A warm dusty medium, or ""dust torus"", is a more likely cause.
• These models can explain the observed anisotropy reasonably well.
• The models suggest that the torus is clumpy rather than smooth.
• The results are consistent with upper limits from the X-ray/MIR correlation of local Seyferts.
• There is some discrepancy with a similar study of nearby Seyferts, which may be due to luminosity or radio power differences.

column1: • **Local Oscillator (LO) Intensity Fluctuation in Continuous Variable Quantum Key Distribution (CVQKD)**

column2: + • **Impact on Secret Key Rate**

column3: - Compromises secret keys if not scaled with instantaneous LO intensity
- Allows Eve to exploit fluctuation for attacks

column2: + • **Eve's LO Intensity Attack (LOIA)**

column3: - Reduces channel excess noise, underestimating Eve's information
- Allows Eve to intercept partial or full secret keys without detection

column2: + • **Reverse Reconciliation**

column3: - More sensitive to LO intensity fluctuation
- Eve can obtain full secret keys with small attenuation

column2: + • **Direct Reconciliation**

column3: - Less affected by LO intensity fluctuation
- Eve can still intercept secret keys with small attenuation

column2: + • **Monitoring LO Intensity**

column3: - Necessary for accurate secret key rate estimation
- Challenging for highly accurate monitoring, especially over long distances

column2: + • **Entangling Cloner Attack**

column3: - Demonstrates Eve's ability to reach the Holevo bound against optimal Gaussian collective attack

column2: + • **LO Intensity Fluctuation Definition**

column3: - Deviation of each pulse's intensity from the initial calibrated value
- Not the quantum fluctuation of each pulse itself

column2: + **Proof of Lower Bound:**

column3: - The proof of the lower bound uses the fact that the principal eigenfunction of the fractional Laplacian is a first integral of the vector field.
- The proof involves conditioning of the process on the principal eigenfunction and using the flow generated by the vector field to characterize the first integrals.
- The proof also uses the fact that the principal eigenfunction is bounded and has a certain decay at the boundary.

column2: + **Proof of Upper Bound:**

column3: - The proof of the upper bound uses the fact that the principal eigenfunction of the fractional Laplacian is a first integral of the vector field.
- The proof involves conditioning of the truncations of the process on the principal eigenfunction and using the flow generated by the vector field to characterize the first integrals.
- The proof also uses the fact that the truncations of the principal eigenfunction are also first integrals.

column2: • Dark matter's nature is still unknown, but it's believed to be a significant component of the universe.

column3: • One hypothesis is that it consists of elementary particles, another is that it includes a significant baryonic component.

column2: • Gamma-ray emission from cosmic-ray interactions within dense gas clouds is a fundamental prediction of models featuring dense gas clouds as dark matter.

column3: • This process could yield a diffuse flux in the galactic plane comparable to the flux from known sources for photon energies around 1 GeV.

column2: • Previous investigations of this problem often neglected self-shielding and cascade phenomena, which can be important at high column densities.

column3: • These effects alter the emergent gamma-ray spectrum and could be relevant to the observed excess galactic flux above 1 GeV.

column2: • The authors used a Monte Carlo simulation code, GEANT4, to calculate gamma-ray spectra from cosmic-ray interactions with dense gas clouds.

column3: • The spectra differ substantially between high and low column-density clouds.
• The results depend primarily on the column density of the clouds and their fractional contribution to the galaxy's dark matter halo.

column2: • The observed intensity of the inner galactic disk at high photon energies (>1 GeV) is substantially greater than expected.

column3: • The existing gamma-ray data, taken in isolation, do not exclude purely baryonic models for the galactic dark halo.
• However, the constraints appropriate to high/low galactic latitudes and the mean intensity of the inner galactic disk should be considered.

column1: - • The outburst of Aql X-1 in 1997 was followed by a sharp decay, similar to dwarf novae outbursts, but with different luminosities and spectra.
- • The quiescent state is characterized by a black body plus a power law spectrum, with a softened black body component and a hardened power law component compared to the decay phase.
- • Aql X-1 likely transitioned to the propeller regime during the outburst decay, with a luminosity gap and a steepening in the decay.
- • After the propeller regime, Aql X-1 may have transitioned to a radio pulsar regime, powering the quiescent luminosity through spin-down energy.
- Massive star that became a Wolf-Rayet star (WCO)
- Thick carbon-rich envelope and circumstellar medium (CSM)
- Early dust formation in the ejecta and CSM
- Hypernova-like explosion model with specific parameters best reproduces the bolometric light curve (LC)
- Ongoing dust formation interpreted as the cause of the rapid decline of the optical LC and brightening of the infrared (IR) LC
- Calculated ejecta-CSM interaction and resulting X-ray LC
- Flat density distribution in the inner CSM indicates a drastic change in mass-loss rate and/or wind velocity
- No specific reason to associate the LBV-like outburst with the presupernova evolution
- Aspherical explosion model with fallback required to match the observed nickel production

column2: + Similar to GRS 1915+105, IGR J17091+0934 exhibits extreme variability and rapid state changes.
+ The extreme variability is believed to be due to a high accretion rate, close to or even higher than the Eddington accretion rate.
+ IGR J17091+0934 also shows large superluminal radio flares and steady radio emission, correlated with specific X-ray variability classes.
+ Despite similar variability patterns, IGR J17091+0934 is about 20 times fainter than GRS 1915+105.
+ Mass, distance, and inclination for IGR J17091+0934 are poorly constrained, but its faintness is difficult to explain even with the most favorable parameters.
+ Simultaneous spectral fitting of IGR J17091+0934's spectra at different phases was performed to better constrain its system parameters.
+ The 'heartbeats' were used as a 'standard candle' to estimate the distance and constrain the parameters.
+ The faintness of IGR J17091+0934 is likely due to its low or negative spin, in contrast to GRS 1915+105's high spin.
+ For inclination angles favored by the data, the black hole in IGR J17091+0934 could have a retrograde spin, a challenging scenario to explain.
+ The research made use of data obtained from the High Energy Astrophysics Science Archive Research Center (HEASARC), provided by NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.
+ Useful discussions with A. R. Rao and comments from the anonymous referee are acknowledged.
+ • The extinction curve describes how extinction changes with wavelength due to dust grains in the interstellar medium.
+ • The Cardelli, Clayton, and Mathis (CCM) law is a one-parameter family of curves that represents the UV to IR extinction law.
+ • The parameter R_v characterizes the dust properties in the region that produces the extinction.
+ • The authors use a sample of 782 stars with known extinction data in the UV.
+ • They apply a χ² minimization method to compute R_v values, weighted by observational errors.
+ • The method takes into account various sources of statistical and systematic errors, including mismatch errors.
+ • The weighted mean of R_v values is found to be 3.1.
+ • The sky distribution of R_v values shows some anisotropy.
+ • The comparison with different calibrations of the V band shows a possible systematic error in R_v values.
+ • Extending the study into other wavelength regions will provide a check on the universality of the CCM law.
+ • The authors plan to discuss this issue in a forthcoming paper.",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"

• Satisfy properties required for computing rank jumps.

column2: + *Triangular Quantum Dot (TQD) Qubit*

column3: - TQD qubit can be controlled by exchange interactions, which can be manipulated by gate potentials.
- Qubit states can be encoded in the doublet subspace, which is immune to decoherence processes.

column2: + *Doublet Blockade Effect*

column3: - A new detection method for read-out of qubit states using current measurement in the doublet blockade regime.
- The method is compatible with purely electrical manipulations and does not require spin-to-charge conversion.

column2: + *Two-Electron Ground State*

column3: - The method can be applied to both singlet and triplet ground states for two electrons.
- The doublet blockade can also be used for dynamical initialization of the qubit state and Landau-Zener passages.

column2: + • SS composed of a white dwarf (WD), red giant (RG), and circumstellar/circumbinary nebulae
+ • Z And consists of a cool giant (M4.5) and a hot compact component (T~1.5x10^5 K)
+ • Z And has shown multiple periods of activity, including 1984-1986 event
+ • Double-peaked structure with low brightness
+ • Caused by WD wind colliding with two RG shells
+ • Minimum due to increased distance between WD and downstream nebula
+ • Detailed spectral modeling reveals physical conditions in nebulae
+ • Shock velocity, density, and ionization parameter varied significantly
+ • WD temperature increased slightly during outburst
+ • Nebula distances from SS center calculated using adjusting factors
+ • Shock front expanded from ~2x10^16 to ~9x10^17 cm (~130 km/s)
+ • Collision with two RG shells occurred within ~2 years
+ • 1984-1986 event remarkable for double-peaked structure and low brightness
+ • Small peaks before and after likely due to RG shell ejections (period ~300-400 days)
+ • No broad lines or jets observed during 1984-1986 outburst

• • Stellar parameters (effective temperature, surface gravity, metallicity, microturbulence) are crucial for chemo-dynamical studies of the Milky Way and other galaxies.
• • Large spectroscopic surveys like SEGUE, RAVE, Gaia-ESO, and HERMES provide data to infer characteristics of different stellar populations.
• • Stellar parameters are determined by spectroscopic methods, with metallicity only measurable through spectroscopy.
• • Atmospheric parameters can be estimated from a spectrum in a consistent and efficient way, avoiding reddening issues.
• • Common methods include ionisation or excitation equilibrium using Fe lines under LTE and HE assumptions.
• • However, LTE assumptions may lead to systematic biases, especially at low metallicity and/or surface gravity.
• • Non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) effects can significantly impact the determination of surface gravity and metallicity.
• • NLTE corrections for Fe lines are necessary to eliminate discrepancies between Fe and Fe lines.
• • NLTE calculations and corrections are available for Fe lines, but not yet for H lines.
• • Effective temperature can be estimated using different methods, such as excitation balance of Fe lines, photometric calibrations, or the infrared flux method (IRFM).
• • Balmer lines provide a reliable method for effective temperature determination in FGK stars.
• • However, systematic biases may affect the Balmer line effective temperature scale due to physical limitations of models.
• • The authors developed a new method (NLTE-Opt) to determine stellar parameters, combining Balmer lines for effective temperature and NLTE ionization balance of Fe lines.
• • This method restricts Fe lines to those with excitation potential > 2 eV to minimize 3D effects.
• • The NLTE-Opt method shows significant systematic biases compared to the widely-used 1D LTE excitation-ionization method of Fe lines (LTE-Fe).

• • The large differences between NLTE-Opt and LTE-Fe estimates of atmospheric parameters have implications for stellar characterization, abundance analyses, and comparisons to stellar evolution models.
• • The authors plan to explore these implications further in subsequent papers, focusing on distance scales, abundance gradients, and the",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
+ • **Observed Correlation:**

column3: - Brighter supernovae (SNe) are behind regions with more foreground galaxies.
- Fainter SNe are behind regions with fewer foreground galaxies.
- This correlation has a slope of -0.3 to -0.4 and a statistical significance of >99.99%.

column2: + • **Modeling Results:**

column3: - Standard mass distribution models struggle to reproduce the observed slope.
- Broader mass distribution models (bifocal pdfs) can explain the observations, but require higher optical depths.
- Biasing has little effect on the slope of the SNe-galaxy relation.

column2: + • **Galactic Dust Interpretation:**

column3: - Galactic dust could potentially explain the observations, but it would require large changes in extinction and galaxy density.
- Dust intrinsic to the structures probed by the APM galaxies cannot explain the observations.
- Current observations indicate that groups and clusters do not contain significant amounts of dust.

column2: + • **Impact on Cosmological Parameters:**

column3: - Weak lensing by intermediate-scale structures probably did not bias the derived values of H0 and OmegaM.
- The distribution of SNe in the foreground galaxy excess (deficit) is indistinguishable from uniform.
- The average SNe magnitude corresponds to the average foreground galaxy excess (deficit).

column2: + The text discusses the behavior of heavy fermion (HF) materials, which are characterized by strong electron correlations and exhibit anomalous physical properties.
+ The periodic anderson model (PAM) and its strong coupling limit, the kondo lattice model, are used to describe these materials.
+ The text emphasizes the importance of understanding the single-particle dynamics and transport properties of these materials to compare theoretical results with experimental data.
+ The text mentions several theoretical approaches to studying the PAM, including:

column3: - Full scale numerical methods such as numerical renormalization group (NRG), quantum Monte Carlo (QMC), and exact diagonalization.

- Theoretical approaches like finite-order perturbation theory, iterated perturbation theory, lattice non-crossing approximation, average matrix approximation, large-N mean-field theory/slave bosons, Gutzwiller variational approach, and the local moment approach (LMA).

column2: + The text notes that most of these methods have limitations and may not be able to handle strong interactions or recover Fermi liquid behavior at low energies.
+ The text focuses on the LMA, which is capable of handling strong interactions and recovering Fermi liquid behavior at low energies.
+ The LMA is based on a two-self-energy description and the concept of symmetry restoration.

+ The text mentions that the LMA has been extended to handle the generic asymmetric PAM and that it enables viable comparison to experiment by providing a many-body description of dynamical and transport properties of paramagnetic HF materials.
