column1: * **Lack of consensus on outcome measures for stroke self-management interventions (smis):**

column2: + Range and number of different published outcome measures adopted by studies
+ Absence of consensus about the concept and operation of self-management in stroke
+ Most smis developed for generic audiences, lacking specific measures for stroke self-management

column1: * **Quality of outcome measures used in stroke smis:**

column2: + Paucity of measures scored 'excellent' or 'good' for quality according to cosmin criteria
+ Measures developed without user involvement scored poorly on content validity
+ Difficulty in determining which measures reflect self-management with validity

column1: * **Future directions for outcome measure development and use in stroke smis:**

column2: + Clarify theoretical premise of the intervention and select outcome measures appropriately
+ Develop measures of self-management with people recovering from stroke
+ Conduct further work to examine the concept and theoretical premises of self-management and develop appropriate measures
+ Correlate KOOS questionnaire with 6-MWT, age, height, weight, and BMI
+ Cross-sectional survey
+ 251 patients with clinical and nonradiographic idiopathic or primary knee OA
+ Inclusion and exclusion criteria applied
+ KOOS self-reported questionnaire (42 questions, 5 domains)
+ 6-MWT (objective performance test)
+ Anthropometric measurements: age, height, weight, BMI
+ 6-MWT had strong to very strong correlations with KOOS subscales (except ADL)
+ BMI had strong to very strong correlations with all KOOS subscales
+ Weight had weak to strong correlations with KOOS subscales (except ADL)
+ Age had weak correlation only with KOOS-QoL subscale
+ KOOS questionnaire correlates well with objective performance test (6-MWT) and anthropometric measurements (BMI, weight) in Indian OA knee patients
+ • Obesity is a global issue due to sedentary lifestyle and high-calorie diets.
+ • It's a low-level, chronic inflammatory disease with multifactorial etiology.
+ • Adipose tissue secretes pro- and anti-inflammatory factors like IL-6, TNF-α, leptin, IL-10, and adiponectin.
+ • High-fat diets promote metabolic changes and chronic inflammation.
+ • Menopause increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases due to changes in lipoprotein profiles, glucose metabolism, and body fat distribution.

column1: • **Study on High-Fat Diet and Ovariectomy in Rats**

column2: + • The study evaluated the effects of a high-fat diet and ovariectomy on inflammation in rats.
+ • Rats were fed a control or high-fat diet for 4 weeks, then divided into sham or ovariectomized groups.
+ • Body weight, food intake, and serum parameters were measured.
+ • Cytokine content in liver, gastrocnemius muscle, and adipose tissues was analyzed.

+ • The study found that a high-fat diet combined with short-term ovariectomy increased body weight gain, food efficiency, and carcass lipid content, but decreased cytokine content in mesenteric adipose tissue.

column1: - • 344 patients underwent bronchial arteriography (BAE) for hemoptysis
- • 234 patients had acute and massive hemoptysis, 110 had chronic and recurrent hemoptysis
- • Hemoptysis volume ranged from 50 to 2000 ml/24 h
- • Chest CT scan identified bleeding lobe in 30.5% of cases
- • Unilateral lung bleeding without exact lobe localization in 36.2%
- • Both lungs had unusual film but not focal hemorrhage in 43.3%
- • Angiography showed abnormal bronchial arteries in 38.1% on the left, 20.0% on the right, and 41.8% bilaterally
- • BAE was performed in 97.7% of patients (336/344)
- • Immediate control of hemoptysis achieved in 96% of patients (330/344)
- • Recurrent hemoptysis within 1 month occurred in 17.7% (61/344)
- • Recurrent hemoptysis over 1 month occurred in 21.5% (74/344)
- • Chest pain in 18.9% (65/344), back pain in 14.8% (51/344), shoulder pain in 8.4% (29/344)
- • Transient dysphagia or lower limb numbness in 0.9% (3/344)
- • 248 patients had telephone follow-up, ranging from 6 months to 8 years

• Aim: To investigate the contribution of celiac disease (CD) and Helicobacter pylori (HP) infection to lymphocytic gastritis (LG) and characterize the immunoprofiles of gastric inflammatory cells in these diseases.

• Design: A retrospective study of 40 patients referred for endoscopy due to upper gastrointestinal symptoms, divided into four groups: normal controls, active CD without HP, HP infection without CD, and active CD with HP infection.
• LG was most prevalent in CD patients without HP infection (50%), followed by CD patients with HP infection (20%), HP-positive patients without CD (8.3%), and none in the control group.

• CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) were significantly higher in CD patients compared to controls and HP-infected patients without CD, suggesting that a higher count of CD8+ IELs may imply CD rather than HP gastritis in undiagnosed patients with LG.
• **Importance of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) Inhibition in Cancer Treatment**
- VEGF is a primary stimulant for tumor angiogenesis, making it a critical target for cancer therapy.
- Bevacizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody that binds human VEGF, is approved for treating metastatic breast cancer.
- Anti-VEGF therapy reduces tumor growth, microvessel density, and macrophage infiltration in breast cancer models.
- It also modulates other immune cell infiltrates, such as myeloid-derived suppressor cells, dendritic cells, and neutrophils.

- 40% expected HCP to initiate conversation, but HCP was initiator only 13% of the time

column1: - Aim: Evaluate lipid peroxidation parameters and total antioxidant capacity in pad patients before and after surgery, and compare with simvastatin-treated patients.
- Group I: Pad patients undergoing surgical treatment (aortobifemoral bypass graft) (n=35, aged 61±8 years).
- Group II: Pad patients receiving simvastatin therapy (20 mg daily) for at least 3 months (n=18, aged 62±7 years).
- Group I patients had higher total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol levels before surgery compared to Group II.
- Group I patients had enhanced oxidative stress, as shown by elevated MDA levels before surgery.
- No significant decrease in lipid peroxidation parameters (LOOH, MDA) was observed in Group I patients after surgery.
- Total antioxidant capacity (FRAP) and thiol group concentrations were similar in both groups before surgery but decreased after surgery in Group I.
- Ceruloplasmin oxidase activity was higher in Group II and increased 710 days after surgery in Group I.
- Lipid peroxidation may contribute to pad development and progression.
- Statin therapy (simvastatin) showed beneficial effects in pad patients by reducing MDA levels and maintaining antioxidant capacity.
- Further studies are needed to clarify the mechanisms and relative importance of lipid-related and non-lipid-related effects of statins in pad.

column2: + Aim: Determine effects of oral and repeated exposure to Fijk herbal remedy on rat plasma biochemical indices and liver morphology.

+ Method: 24 male Wistar rats were divided into four groups and administered Fijk at doses of 15, 30, or 45 mg/kg body weight or distilled water (control) daily for 21 days. Biochemical analysis and histopathological examinations were conducted.
+ Lipid Profile:

column3: - No significant change in total cholesterol.
- Dose-dependent increase in triglycerides and LDL-C.
- Decreased HDL-C levels with increasing doses.
- Elevated atherogenic index.

column2: + Liver Function Tests:

column3: - Decreased alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels at highest dose.
- Increased ALT and AST levels at all doses.

column2: + Oxidative Stress Markers:

column3: - Increased MDA levels (lipid peroxidation).
- Decreased GSH levels.

column2: + Control group: Normal liver architecture.
+ Fijk-treated groups: Hepatic alterations including hemorrhage, ruptured vascular channels, hyperemia, and inflammation.
+ Repeated consumption of Fijk may increase the risk of cardiovascular disorders and liver injury.
+ More studies are needed to validate these findings and assess the safety of Fijk herbal remedy.

column2: • Aim: To determine if L-AAA treatment inhibits Müller cell gliosis and protects against retinal abnormalities in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension (AOH) mimicking glaucoma.
• Methodology:

column3: - Used adult male Sprague-Dawley rats.
- Induced AOH by increasing intraocular pressure (IOP) to 110 mmHg for 60 minutes.
- Divided animals into four groups: sham operation (Ctrl), AOH, AOH + PBS control, and AOH + L-AAA treated.
- Injected L-AAA (250 µg) into vitreous humor after 3 hours of AOH induction.
- Performed time-course examination at 1 day, 3 days, and 5 days after AOH.

column2: • L-AAA treatment attenuated retinal ganglion cell (RGC) apoptosis and rescued the reduced number of RGCs in AOH retinas.
• L-AAA treatment inhibited Müller cell gliosis and downregulated TNF-α protein production in the rat model of AOH.

column1: * **Laparoscopy-Assisted Endoscopic Full-Thickness Resection with Ligation Device (LAEFTR-L) for Nonampullary Superficial Duodenal Neoplasms**

column1: • Caused by defects in enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis, with 90-95% due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD)
• Symptoms include ambiguous genitalia in females, rapid growth, and accelerated skeletal maturation
• Managed with oral glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid administration to compensate for adrenal steroid deficiencies and suppress adrenal androgens
• Four cases of CAH managed with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone
• Adrenal masses found in all four cases, with two undergoing adrenalectomy due to increasing mass size and virilization
• Autosomal recessive condition caused by deletions or mutations in the cytochrome P450 21-hydroxylase gene
• Two forms: classic (severe) and non-classic (mild or late-onset)
• Classic form further subclassified as salt-losing or simple virilizing
• Non-classic form may be asymptomatic or associated with signs of androgen excess
• Diagnosed through newborn screening programs or corticotropin stimulation test
• Aim of medical treatment: suppress adrenal androgens without impairing growth and allowing normal pubertal development and fertility
• Glucocorticoids given in doses sufficient to suppress excessive secretion of CRH and ACTH
• Fludrocortisone used in cases of salt-losing manifestation and elevated plasma renin activity

column2: + Examined the relationship between dietary and physical activity behaviors and self-rated health (SRH)
+ Used data from the Living for Health program (2008-2012) in Miami-Dade County, Florida
+ Included 1,701 adults, primarily minorities (half Hispanic, predominantly black non-Hispanics)
+ Lower fruit and vegetable intake and higher fat intake were associated with poor/fair SRH in both males and females
+ Physical inactivity was significantly associated with poor/fair SRH in females, but not in males after adjusting for covariates
+ Gender differences in physical activity levels and SRH were observed, with women being less active and more likely to report poor/fair SRH
+ Modifiable lifestyle behaviors can impact SRH, suggesting potential targets for cardiovascular disease prevention interventions
+ Gender differences may need to be considered in designing and monitoring such interventions
+ Limitations include cross-sectional design, lack of data on socioeconomic status, neighborhood, housing situation, and psychosocial factors

column1: * **Endoscopic Injection of Dextranomer/Hyaluronic Acid (DX/HA) for Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR)**
- Approved by FDA in 2001 for grade II-IV VUR in single systems without malformations in children over 1 year.
- Usage expanded to include patients of all ages and grades, even with anomalies like duplication or ureterocele.
- Initial success rate quoted as 68%, improved to 89% with the Hydrodistention-Implantation Technique (HIT).
- Our institution's overall success rate is 75% for patients and 84% for renal units after the first injection.

column2: + *Prevalence and Classification*

column3: - Prevalence of ventriculomegaly ranges between 0.3 - 1.5%
- Severity classified as mild (10 - 12 mm), moderate (12 - 15 mm), and severe (>15 mm)

column2: + *Causes of Ventriculomegaly*

column3: - Imbalance between CSF production and absorption (obstructive form most common)
- Abnormal cerebral development (agenesis of corpus callosum, neuronal migration disorders)
- Destructive disease processes (vascular insults, infectious pathogens)

column2: + *Additional Anomalies and Prognosis*

column3: - Incidence of additional anomalies up to 70-85%, depending on severity and study population
- Isolated and/or unilateral ventriculomegaly has lower morbidity and mortality

column2: + *MRI Technique and Advantages*

column3: - Mainly performed on 1.5T scanners, with no demonstrated adverse effects
- HASTE sequence most used, with good signal-to-noise ratio and spatial resolution
- Excellent contrast resolution, allowing differentiation between gray and white matter

column2: + *Limitations of MRI*

column3: - Fetal motion and lower spatial resolution compared to ultrasound
- Contra-indications similar to non-pregnant patients (claustrophobia, metallic implants, etc.)

column2: + *Role of MRI in Ventriculomegaly Diagnosis*

column3: - Detection and characterization of additional cerebral anomalies
- Limited role in assessing ventricle size, except when fetal position or calvarial ossification causes problems
- Useful in detecting small foci of brain hemorrhage, callosal anomalies, and white matter pathology

column1: * **Added Value of MRI in Ventriculomegaly Diagnosis**

column2: + *Moderate and Severe Ventriculomegaly*

column3: - Confirms severity and detects/characterizes additional anomalies
- Useful in detecting small foci of brain hemorrhage or callosal anomalies in the second trimester

column2: + *Mild Unilateral Ventriculomegaly*

column3: - May demonstrate additional findings difficult to detect with sonography (leucomalacia, neuronal migration disorders)
- Might provide more information about normal/pathological cortical development and maturation in late pregnancy

+ Lung cancer is the third most common cancer and the leading cause of cancer-related death in the US.
+ In 2012, an estimated 226,160 patients were diagnosed with lung cancer, and 160,340 died from the disease.
+ At diagnosis, 56% of lung cancer cases were distant metastasis, 22% were regional metastasis, 15% were localized, and 8% were unstaged.
+ Five-year relative survival was 3.5% for distant stage, 24% for regional stage, and 52.9% for localized stage.
+ Bone is a common site of metastasis in lung cancer, with 19.8% of patients aged 65 or older having possible bone metastasis within a year of diagnosis.
+ SREs, such as fractures, radiotherapy to bone, surgery to bone, and spinal cord compression, occurred in 51% of patients with bone metastasis.
+ Having a possible bone metastasis was associated with mortality among lung cancer patients.
+ The association was similar for bone metastasis complicated with an SRE and for bone metastasis without an SRE.
+ Bone metastases were more common in patients with distant stage lung cancer (38%) than in those with regional (12%), unstaged (11%), or localized (5%) stages.
+ Radiotherapy to bone was the most common SRE (81% of patients with SRE), followed by fracture (14%), spinal cord compression (6%), and surgery to bone (1%).
+ Pathological fractures occurred in 65% of patients with fractures, with the spine being the most common site.
+ The study was limited to patients aged 65 or older diagnosed with lung cancer between 1999 and 2005, with Medicare Part A and B coverage, and residing in SEER geographic areas.
+ The study did not validate the procedures used to identify bone metastasis and may have missed true cases or included false positives.
+ Other confounding factors, such as treatment factors or",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
• Aim: Compare the effect of photodynamic diode laser and other smear layer removal methods on bond strength of self-adhesive cement.
• Null Hypothesis: No significant differences in push-out bond strength values after different root canal surface treatments.
• 55 extracted maxillary central incisors used.
• Teeth prepared with rotary instruments, filled with gutta percha, and post spaces created.
• Teeth randomly divided into 5 groups based on post space treatments: NaCl, NaOCl, EDTA, H3PO4, and Photodynamic Diode Laser.
• Posts luted with self-adhesive resin cement, and push-out bond strength tested.
• Higher bond strength values for Helbo Theralite Laser and 37% Orthophosphoric Acid groups.
• Mixed failures (dentin-cement and post-cement) in NaCl, NaOCl, EDTA, and H3PO4 groups; post-cement failure in Helbo Theralite Laser group.
• Null hypothesis rejected due to significant differences among groups.
• Photodynamic diode laser increased bond strength without removing smear layer, possibly due to collagen fibril stability.
• NaOCl and NaCl were not effective in smear layer removal and bond strength improvement.
• EDTA and H3PO4 were effective in smear layer removal but not as effective as Helbo Theralite Laser and H3PO4 in bond strength.
• Modifying smear layer may be more effective when using self-adhesive systems.

column2: • Aim: To evaluate acute haemodynamic response (AHR) of implanted CRT systems and alternative LV endocardial pacing sites in clinical non-responders.
• Participants: 24 non-consecutive patients (23 males, age 72.8 ± 9.1 years, mean EF 22.5 ± 7.1%) who remained in NYHA class III/IV despite ≥6 months of CRT and optimal medical therapy.
• Acute haemodynamic study using a 6F multipurpose angioplasty guiding catheter and a Medtronic 6416 temporary bipolar screw-in lead.
• LV pacing performed from basal posterolateral, mid-posterioral, LV apical, and LV septal locations, with optimal AHR obtained after optimisation of the CRT system for all positions.
• A rise in LVdp/dtmax ≥15% from baseline considered a positive haemodynamic response.
• 11 patients showed a positive response to LV endocardial pacing, with optimal positions in the apical (7), anterolateral (2), and mid-posterioral (2) regions.
• 13 patients had a negative response to LV endocardial pacing, with suboptimal positions in the basal posterolateral (3), mid-posterioral (8), and apical (2) regions.
• 5 out of 9 acute haemodynamic non-responders with LBBB had their AHR increased above the 15% level by LV endocardial pacing.
• Average AHR with the coronary sinus system was 9.6% (5.8-14.9%), and at the LV endocardial optimal position, it was 25.8% (19.0-34.3%).
• Ten patients were considered possible candidates for LV endocardial pacing, with 5 agreeing to the procedure after deliberation.
• All five patients improved clinically with a reduction of at least 1 class in the NYHA score after 6 months of follow-up.
• Two patients refrained from implantation, and one patient improved after changing stimulation to a more basal position and optimising intervals.
• One patient's deterioration was due to a blunted chronotropic response after increasing beta-blocker dosage following an episode of atrial fibrillation.
+ *Diagnosis*: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)
+ *Age*: 35 years
+ *Gestation*: Full term primigravida
+ *Complications*: Oligohydramnios, renal insufficiency
+ *Symptoms*: Flank pain, generalized swelling, decreased urine output
+ *Investigations*: Hemoglobin 10.2 gm%, BUN 30 mg/dL, Serum Creatinine 3.7 mg%, normal LFTs, coagulation profile within normal limits
+ *Treatment*: Hemodialysis thrice a week for 2 months
+ *Decision*: Emergency Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS)
+ *Anesthesia*: Spinal anesthesia with 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine (5 mg) and fentanyl (25 mcg)
+ *Intraoperative Parameters*: BP 100-120 mmHg systolic, HR 70-100/min, CVP 5-6 cm H2O, urine output ~1 mL/min
+ *Delivery*: Live male child (2.0 kg), APGAR score 9 at 5 min
+ *Postoperative Care*: Intravenous tramadol 8 hourly, no hemodialysis required
+ *Renal Disease Exacerbation*: Unknown pathophysiology, possibly due to increased glomerular perfusion or microvascular injury
+ *Renal Function Changes*: Increased GFR, tubular sodium reabsorption and osmoregulation reset, modest proteinuria
+ *Risk Factors*: Serum creatinine >2.0 mg/dL increases risk of dialysis-dependent end-stage renal disease
+ *Patient's Renal Function*: Diagnosed in seventh month, blood erythrocyte count and hematocrit possibly increased due to abnormal erythropoietin production
+ *Hemodialysis*: Thrice a week, early dialysis recommended during pregnancy
+ *Anesthesia Considerations*: Normal coagulation profile, no hemorrhagic complications observed in thrombocytopenic patients, maintain high suspicion for neurological complications postoperatively
+ *Spinal Anesthesia*: Low dose of local",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: * **Lactation Curve and Milk Yield in Normal and Mastitis Crossbred Cows**

column2: + *Peak Milk Yield*

column3: - Normal cows: Peak at 3rd and 4th fortnight (td-3 and td-4)
- Mastitis cows: Peak at 3rd fortnight (td-3)
- Both groups: Decline in milk yield after peak

column2: + *Parity-wise Milk Yield*

column3: - 1st parity: Lower initial and peak milk yield, more time to peak
- 4th parity: Maximum milk yield in both normal and mastitis cows
- 5th parity and above: Decline in milk yield in both groups

column2: + *Lactation Curve Parameters*

column3: - Initial milk yield (a): Higher in normal cows, increased with parity
- Ascending slope (b): Similar in 1st parity, declined in 2nd, increased in subsequent parities
- Descending slope (c): Lower in 1st parity, higher in 4th and 5th parity in normal cows; minimum in 1st parity, maximum in 5th and above in mastitis cows

column2: + *Persistency of Lactation*

column3: - Higher in 1st parity, declined till 5th and above parity in all cows
- Better feed utilization and less susceptibility to disorders in 1st parity

column2: + *Gamma Type Function*

column3: - Good fit for predicting milk yield in both normal and mastitis cows
- Atypical lactation curves observed in about one-third of cows

column2: + *Comparison with Previous Reports*

column3: - Peak milk yield, initial milk yield, and persistency trends similar to previous reports
- Heritability estimates suggest these traits can be included in selection schemes

column2: + Mice fed with NDGA at 3.5g/kg diet (373mg/kg body weight/day) had a 12% increase in median lifespan.
+ No effect on maximum lifespan.
+ Dose-response relationship was observed, with only this dose extending lifespan.
+ NDGA consumption increased liver, lung, and thymus tumors, and hemorrhagic diathesis.
+ NDGA decreased liver tumor size but increased tumor number.
+ No acute liver or kidney toxicity was observed.
+ NDGA at 3.0mg/ml medium increased median lifespan by approximately 23%.
+ No effect on food consumption, body weight, or locomotor activity.
+ Inhibition of mTORC1 activity is a probable mechanism for NDGA's longevity effects.
+ NDGA's effects on tumor growth and formation suggest it increases tumor formation while reducing growth rates.
+ Hormetic stimuli, antioxidant effects, and inhibition of inflammation and oxidative phosphorylation are less likely mechanisms.
+ *Genetic Variation Contributes to Disease Susceptibility and Treatment Response*

column1: • **Myosin Va (MyoVa) as a Processive Molecular Motor**

column2: • **Structure and Function**

column3: - Dimerized molecule with n-terminal motor domains (heads), lever arms, coiled-coil rod domain, and c-terminal cargo-binding domain
- Directed movement achieved by conformational change in motor domain following ATP hydrolysis, amplified by lever arms for processive motion

column2: • **Calcium-Dependent Regulation**

column3: - Calcium required for ATP hydrolysis activity; high calcium reduces motor processivity and may dissociate calmodulin from lever arms
- Calmodulin dissociation may reduce lever arm displacement amplification and strain-dependent gating between heads, impacting motor processivity

column1: • **Tethered Particle Microscopy (TPM) to Measure Flexural Stiffness**

column2: • **Methodology**

column3: - Anchored MyoVa-actin complex to microscope slide and attached fluorescent quantum dot (Qdot) to desired location along motor
- Thermal energy-induced random displacement of Qdot measured by comparing tethered Qdot image size to stationary reference Qdot

column2: • **Findings**

column3: - Lever arm flexural stiffness estimated to be 0.0346 pN/nm with corresponding persistence length of 242 nm
- Calcium addition reduced lever arm flexural stiffness by 40%, indicating compromised interhead communication and gating

column2: + Determine if clinical outcome after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) can be predicted by functional polymorphisms in proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.
+ Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in aurka, erbb2, mdm2, cdh1, cdkn2a, and tp73 genes were genotyped.
+ 346 esophageal cancer patients who underwent surgical resection with curative intent between 1996 and 2001.
+ No significant associations found in univariate analysis for any of the tested polymorphisms in EAC or ESCC patients.
+ In multivariate analysis:

column3: - Patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous mdm2 (rs2279744) t/g genotype had significantly improved DFS compared to those with the wild-type t/t genotype (adjusted hazard ratio (AHR) = 0.63, 95% CI [0.45-0.88], p = 0.007).

- Patients with EAC harboring the homozygous cdh1 (rs5030625) ga/ga genotype had significantly reduced survival compared to those with the wild-type g/g genotype (AHR = 4.0, 95% CI [1.4-11], p = 0.008).

column2: + Improved survival in patients with the mdm2 t/g genotype may be due to interaction with tumor p53 status, as shown in a breast cancer study.
+ The cdh1 ga/ga genotype may enhance esophageal cancer progression by reducing cdh1 transcription and impairing cell-cell adhesion.
+ Larger studies with genome-wide association approaches and prospective validation of the identified associations are needed.
+ Identification of high-risk patients for disease recurrence may enable targeted adjuvant treatment.

column1: • 50 HIV-positive patients from Saint-Antoine Hospital's odontology unit
• Most common oral lesions: periodontal disease, herpetic lesions, hairy leukoplakia, gingivitis, oral ulceration, Kaposi's sarcoma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma
• Most common OPCC clinical presentations: pseudomembranous (52.6%), erythematous (13.15%), angular cheilitis (13.15%), and combinations thereof
• Most frequent candida species: C. albicans (92%), followed by C. tropicalis (5.26%) and C. glabrata (2.64%)
• 62% of oral lesions occurred at CD4+ count < 200 cells/mm³
• 73% of OPCC cases had CD4+ counts < 200 cells/mm³
• Median duration of ART was 2 years
• ART reduces OPCC, but it remains a significant clinical sign in HIV-positive patients
• **Study Aim**: To evaluate the performance of three different-sized SPIOs for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) in a porcine model.
• • **Tracers Used**: Ferumoxytol (32 nm), Sienna+ (59 nm), and Ferumoxide (111 nm)
• • **Method**: Subcutaneous injection, transcutaneous magnetometer measurements, surgical excision, and histopathological evaluation
• • **Outcome Measures**: SLN identification rate, number of SLNs identified, magnetometer counts, iron content, and iron deposition patterns
• • **SLN Identification**: Successful in all cases for 32 nm and 59 nm tracers, and in 11/12 cases for 111 nm tracer
• • **Number of SLNs Identified**: More nodes per basin excised with 32 nm tracer compared to others
• • **Magnetometer Counts**: Significantly higher with 59 nm tracer compared to others
• • **Iron Content**: Significantly higher for 59 nm tracer compared to 32 nm tracer only
• • **Tracer Selection**: 59 nm tracer showed optimal performance for rapid uptake, retention, and accumulation in SLNs
• • **Clinical Application**: Further studies needed to optimize injection-to-surgery time for each tracer
• • **Safety**: No adverse events observed in animals, and iron overload unlikely with small injected doses
• • **Regulatory Status**: Only 59 nm tracer is currently CE-marked for SLNB in Europe

column2: + Aim: To compare serum vaspin and adiponectin levels in subjects with normal renal function and renal insufficiency with or without type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
+ Design: Cross-sectional study involving 416 subjects, divided into four groups based on the presence or absence of renal insufficiency (RI) and T2DM.
+ Serum vaspin levels were not significantly different between patients with and without RI, regardless of T2DM status.
+ Serum vaspin levels were lower in patients with T2DM compared to those without T2DM.

+ Serum adiponectin levels were higher in patients with RI compared to those without RI, regardless of T2DM status. However, there was no significant difference in adiponectin levels between diabetic patients with and without RI.
+ Serum vaspin levels were correlated with creatinine clearance (CrCl), total cholesterol (TC), and hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) in all subjects.
+ Serum adiponectin levels were correlated with age, systolic blood pressure (SBP), CrCl, creatinine (Cr), blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and HbA1c in all subjects.
+ After adjusting for multiple factors, only HbA1c was independently associated with serum vaspin levels, and only CrCl was independently associated with serum adiponectin levels in all subjects.

column1: - Aim: To test surrogate variables for neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and explore correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing.
- Design: Two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials and an active postmarketing surveillance study.
- Diabetic patients (type 1 or 2), both sexes, >18 years of age.
- Excluded: Chronic, uncontrolled illness, psychiatric or neurologic diseases, neoplasia, pregnancy, or breastfeeding.
- Intralesional injections of recombinant human epidermal growth factor (rHEGF) at 75 or 25 µg, three times per week, up to complete granulation or a maximum of 8 weeks.
- Adjuvant standard care: thorough debridement, moist dressing, pressure offloading, and antibiotics if necessary.
- Percent change in area, log healing rate, ratio of log areas at the 2nd week and end of treatment (EOT), and percent granulation tissue covering the ulcer area.
- Imputation of missing data using last observation carried forward (LOCF) or average between two contiguous evaluations.
- Area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve for each candidate surrogate variable.
- Sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive values (PV+), negative predictive values (PV-), and correct classification index for each surrogate variable.
- Product coefficient (PC) to quantify the contribution of candidate surrogates to the final outcome.
- Granulation tissue development showed good capacity to discriminate healers from nonhealers with ROC curve areas >70% at the 2nd week and EOT.
- Proportion mediated for granulation variables was very high, suggesting that granulation is an essential part of the healing process.
- Area change-dependent candidates had a small proportion mediated.
- Models for final cicatrization and granulation surrogates were adequate and fulfilled Prentice criteria for surrogate end points.
- Treatment had a significant effect upon the surrogate end point, the true end point, and the surrogate had a significant effect upon the true end point.
- EOT >75% granulation had a higher positive predictive value (PV+) for final re-epit",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"

column2: + Compare perioperative extent of surgical trauma and its postoperative impact on the abdominal wall after NTAPP and STAPP repair
+ Retrospective cohort study with institutional review board approval
+ 85 patients with single-sided primary inguinal hernia between November 1, 2009, and July 31, 2012
+ Comparable at baseline between NTAPP and STAPP groups
+ Male:Female ratio around 5:1
+ Age around 50 years
+ BMI around 25 kg/m²
+ Direct:Indirect:Pantaloon hernia ratio around 30:55:10%
+ Hernia diameter around 2.3 cm
+ NTAPP: 8-mm umbilical trocar, 5-mm right trocar, 2-mm left trocar
+ STAPP: Gelpoint advanced-access platform, 5-mm optical trocar, two 5-mm working trocars
+ Self-fixating Parietene ProGrip mesh used in both groups
+ Umbilical skin incision length
+ Operative time
+ Length of postoperative hospital stay
+ Hernia recurrence
+ Postoperative pain (VAS)
+ Postoperative mobility of the abdominal wall (Janda's test)
+ Postoperative cosmetic satisfaction (VAS)
+ Period of sick leave after hospital discharge
+ NTAPP: Shorter umbilical skin incision length (13.4 mm vs. 27.3 mm)
+ NTAPP: Significantly less operating time (54.8 minutes vs. 85.9 minutes)
+ No significant difference in length of postoperative hospital stay
+ No inguinal or port-site hernia in either group
+ NTAPP: Less immediate postoperative pain and shorter sick leave
+ No significant difference in hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, or cosmetic satisfaction
+ NTAPP procedure minimizes surgical trauma, reduces operating time, and improves immediate postoperative outcomes compared to STAPP
+ Long-term results in hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction are comparable between NTAPP and STAPP
+ Randomized controlled trials are needed to validate the benefits of needlescopic",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: • • Caused by: Hypertrophy of pharyngeal/palatine tonsils, nasal mucosa/turbinate edema, nasal septal deviation, extended suction habits, etc.

• • Consequences: Maximillary hypoplasia, posterior mandibular demotion/rotation, dental occlusion alterations, vertical facial growth pattern, hard palate elevation, head anteriorization, muscular deharmonization.
• • Effects on functions: Alterations in speech, chewing, deglutition.
• • Professionals involved: Otorhinolaryngologists, odontologists, phonoaudiologists, physiotherapists, pediatricians, etc.
• • Importance of uniform categorization and terminology.
• • Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment to minimize relapse.
• • Nasopharyngoscopy: Gold standard exam, provides dynamic and tridimensional view.
• • Cephalometry: Complementary exam, provides information about craniofacial growth.
• • Correlation between exams: Regular and positive, but cephalometry tends to underestimate pharyngeal tonsil size.
• • Correlation coefficient (r) between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry: 0.52.
• • Patients with mouth-breathing symptoms and normal radiography should be referred for nasopharyngoscopy.
• • Nasopharyngoscopy is suggested when cephalometry results for nasopharyngeal obstruction are negative.

column2: • • Diagnosed with IDC in 2004 at 35 years old, ER+/PR+/HER2-
• • Treated with lumpectomy, adjuvant chemotherapy (AC), radiotherapy, and tamoxifen
• • Developed inflammatory breast cancer in the same breast in 2008, ER-/PR+/HER2+
• • Treated with weekly paclitaxel, carboplatin, and trastuzumab
• • Followed by adjuvant weekly paclitaxel and trastuzumab, then trastuzumab monotherapy
• • Underwent breast reconstruction surgery
• • Remains in complete clinical remission after 4 years and 8 months
• • Genetic testing negative for known breast cancer-associated mutations
• • Regular follow-up and screening due to increased risk of contralateral breast cancer

column1: * **Study on Anti-VEGF Treatment Switch in AMD**

column2: + **Objective**

column3: - Evaluate change in Pelli-Robson CS as primary end point
- Assess mean change in BCVA, CRT, and NEI VFQ-25 score

column2: + **Study Design**

column3: - Single-center, IRB-approved, prospective, interventional, non-controlled, single-arm study
- 40 neovascular AMD patients switched from ranibizumab to aflibercept

column2: + **Results**

column3: - Significant improvement in CS (p=0.00079) at week 12
- Stable VA, significant decrease in CRT (p=0.004)
- 65% of patients showed improvement in NEI VFQ-25 score

column2: + **Conclusion**

column3: - CS improvement may indicate better vision-related functional performance
- CS should be considered as an additional outcome end point in future clinical studies

column2: • Evaluate association between c424c/a polymorphism in IL-25 gene and MS in Iranian population
• Case-control study
• 74 MS patients (RRMS) and 75 healthy controls
• Age and gender matched
• Exclusion criteria: genetic diseases, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, smokers
• Blood samples from MS patients at Sina Hospital and healthy controls from Tehran Blood Transfusion Services
• DNA purification using commercial kit
• PCR amplification and RFLP (using BsrFI enzyme) for exon 2 of IL-25 gene
• Independent two-sample t-test for continuous variables
• Chi-square test for categorical variables
• Logistic regression model for odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence interval (CI)
• No significant difference in genotype (aa, ac, cc) and allele (a, c) frequencies between MS patients and healthy controls
• No significant association between c424c/a polymorphism and MS development
• c424c/a polymorphism in IL-25 gene is not associated with MS and not a risk factor for MS development

column1: • 542 consecutive Korean male hypertensive patients, aged 65 and above, without history of aortic aneurysm.
• Prospective study using non-contrast CT to measure aortic diameters from June 2012 to April 2013.
• TAA: older age, larger body surface area, higher diastolic blood pressure, absence of dyslipidemia, presence of AAA.
• AAA: presence of dyslipidemia, current/past smoking, presence of TAA.
• High prevalence of TAA, more common than AAA, in elderly Korean males with hypertension and multiple risk factors.
• Need for distinct screening strategies for TAA and AAA based on risk factors and ethnicity.
• Limitations: CT scan with axial images may not accurately evaluate the aortic root, and results may not be applicable to females, other ethnicities, or low-risk groups.

column2: • Aim: Investigate liquid-based SurePath preparation for endometrial cytology test (ECT) to maintain 3D structure of endometrium.
• Background: Endometrial cancer morbidity has exceeded cervical cancer in developed countries. Effective screening methods are needed.
• Prospective study from Nov 2011 to May 2014 at Peking University First Hospital.
• 1514 patients with endometrial cancer risk factors underwent ECT using SAP-1 device, and 375 also underwent D&C or hysteroscopy.
• SAP-1 device: Flexible latex loop with spines, outer protective sheath, easy to operate.
• SurePath cell preservation container and semi-automated slide processor used for processing.
• Two independent gynecological cytologists evaluated smears.
• Results subdivided into four categories: negative, benign, atypical, suspected malignant.
• Two gynecological pathologists assessed slides based on WHO criteria and EIN.
• D&C or hysteroscopic pathology was final result for normal or benign endometrium.
• SAP-1 provided more sufficient materials for cytology than D&C or hysteroscopic biopsy (p < 0.01).
• No difference in adequacy between cytology and biopsy in premenopausal women (p = 0.919).
• Easier to collect cytology specimens than histology specimens in postmenopausal women (p < 0.05).
• Accuracy of cytology for detecting endometrial precursor and carcinoma: 91.7%.
• Sensitivity: 73.6%, Specificity: 94.9%, PPV: 71.9%, NPV: 95.3%.
• SAP-1 superior to D&C in specimen adequacy (96.3% vs 76%).
• No pain reported during SAP-1 sampling, similar to cytobrush insertion.
• SAP-1 sampler combined with SurePath preparation is reliable for screening endometrial carcinoma and its precursor.
• Further investigation needed to improve accuracy, especially for focal atypical lesions.
+ *Prevalence and Mortality*

column3: - Most common cancer in women worldwide
- Highest incidence rates in Europe and North America

column2: + *Mammography Screening*

column3: - Digital mammography (DM) as effective as screen-film mammography (SFM)
- DM less likely to be lost or damaged and has slightly higher sensitivity

column2: + *Overlapping Tissue*

column3: - Breast cancers can be obscured by overlapping tissue
- Tumors may be hidden in dense fibroglandular tissue

column2: + *False Positives and Missed Lesions*

column3: - High false-positive rates and missed lesions due to overlapping tissue
- Recall for additional imaging can lead to false-positive biopsies

column2: + *Technique and Advantages*

column3: - Uses x-rays to create image slices of breast tissue
- Improves visualization of breast anatomy by separating tissues into different planes

column2: + *Clinical Performance*

column3: - Emerging evidence shows increased mammogram accuracy and reduced recall rates
- Can detect additional invasive malignancies missed by conventional mammography

column2: + *Radiation Exposure*

column3: - DBT radiation exposure similar to SFM or DM
- Synthetically reconstructed 2D images can reduce radiation dose to conventional mammography levels

column2: + *Patient Comfort*

column3: - DBT can be done with less compression, improving patient satisfaction
- May decrease the need for supplementary mammogram views and extra imaging

column2: + *Cost*

column3: - DBT systems are more expensive than DM systems
- Potential cost savings from reduced biopsies and recalls

column2: + *Integration with Other Modalities*

column3: - Being studied in combination with contrast-enhanced tomosynthesis and automated breast ultrasound
- Computer-assisted detection and dual-energy contrast-enhanced DM also being explored

column2: + Aimed to evaluate the effect of a diphenhydramine-containing syrup on cough reflex sensitivity in adults with acute URI.
+ Found that diphenhydramine significantly inhibited cough reflex sensitivity compared to placebo.
+ Dextromethorphan, another common OTC antitussive, did not show significant inhibition compared to placebo.
+ Diphenhydramine was more effective than dextromethorphan at the standard antitussive doses used.
+ Double-blind, crossover study with 22 adult nonsmokers with acute URI.
+ Subjects received diphenhydramine, dextromethorphan, and placebo in random order, 2 hours before capsaicin challenge testing.
+ Five subjects reported slight drowsiness after diphenhydramine, and five reported side effects after dextromethorphan (slight drowsiness, slight nausea, dry mouth).
+ This study provides the first evidence of diphenhydramine's ability to inhibit cough reflex sensitivity in acute URI.
+ Further clinical trials are needed to adequately evaluate OTC cough and cold products.
+ • Increased cardiovascular risk factors and diseases with age
+ • Endothelium's role in vascular function and health
+ • Oxidative stress and inflammation as key factors in endothelial aging
+ • Imbalance between oxidizing agents and antioxidant systems
+ • Reduction in nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability due to increased superoxide production
+ • Increased production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS)
+ • Chronic, low-grade inflammation in aged endothelium
+ • Increased expression of proinflammatory cytokines and adhesion molecules
+ • Activation of the NF-κB pathway and increased levels of inflammatory markers
+ • Regular exercise improves endothelial function in the elderly
+ • Restoration of NO availability and prevention of oxidative stress
+ • Upregulation of antioxidant defense mechanisms and reduction in lipid peroxidation
+ • Increased shear stress and upregulation of endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS)
+ • Activation of Nrf2 and increased expression of antioxidant enzymes
+ • Reduction in inflammation through modulation of cytokines (e.g., IL-6, TNF-α)
+ • Increased arterial compliance with regular aerobic exercise
+ • Reduction in plasma endothelin-1 (ET-1) levels and elimination of ET-1-mediated vascular tone
+ • Short-term inflammatory response followed by long-term anti-inflammatory adaptations
+ • Reduction in CRP, IL-6, and TNF-α levels, and increase in anti-inflammatory substances (e.g., IL-4, IL-10)

column1: • **Axillary Lymph Node Status and Prognosis in Breast Carcinoma**
• Prognosis worsens with increasing number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• AJCC/UICC TNM classification groups nodal disease based on the number of metastatic lymph nodes.
• Studies show that the number of metastatic lymph nodes increases with the number of removed lymph nodes.
• Lymph node ratio (LNR) provides more useful prognostic information than the number of metastatic lymph nodes alone.
• Different studies have varying LNR threshold values for prognostic significance.
• The study evaluates the prognostic significance of the number of removed and metastatic lymph nodes, and LNR in breast carcinoma patients with 1-3 axillary metastatic lymph nodes.
• The study found that LNR is a more powerful prognostic factor than the number of metastatic lymph nodes for distant metastasis-free survival.

column2: + • **Enzyme Selection**

column3: - Phonse (Salmonella typhimurium)
- Phonsf (Shigella flexneri)
- Piacp (Prevotella intermedia)

column2: + • **Substrate Scope**

column3: - Primary and secondary mono/diols
- Cyclic substrates
- Haloalcohols
- Aminoalcohols (only o-phosphorylation)

column2: + • **Regioselectivity**

column3: - Prim > Sec hydroxyl groups
- No bisphosphorylation of short-chain diols
- Enantioselectivity: marginal preference for (R)-1,2-propanediol by phonse

column2: + • **Chemoselectivity**

column3: - o-Nucleophiles > n/s-nucleophiles
- No phosphorylation of charged groups or n/s-nucleophiles

column2: + • **Kinetic Control**

column3: - High substrate loads required
- Phosphate donors: ppi, pppi, polyp
- Ph: 3.5-4.2 (optimal for phonsf and piacp with pppi)

column2: + • **Scale-up**

column3: - Immobilized phonsf on Relizyme HA
- Flow reactor: 6.86 g (41% yield) of 4-hydroxybutyl phosphate

column1: * **History and Growth of Invasion Biology Research**

column2: + *Early Notices and Limited Response*

column3: - Phylloxera and chestnut blight noted in the 19th century
- Charles Elton's book in 1958 had limited impact

column2: + *SCOPE Project and Research Explosion*

column3: - International project in the mid-1980s
- Triggered extensive research on invasions

column2: + *Ecosystem-Level Impacts*

column3: - Nutrient cycles, fire cycles, hydrology affected
- Examples: Fukami et al. study on impacts

column2: + *Genetics and Evolution*

column3: - Hybridization, introgression, and novel species
- Genetic tracing of invasions and environmental DNA (eDNA)

column2: + *Criticisms of Invasion Biology*

column3: - Problems are overblown, similar impacts from natives
- Introduced species increase native biodiversity

column2: + *Key Ecological Criticisms*

column3: - Which species really cause harm?
- Can we effectively manage invasions?

column2: + *Prevention and Early Detection*

column3: - Risk assessment tools for potential invaders
- Biosecurity and early detection technologies

column2: + *Eradication and Control*

column3: - Eradication successes and challenges
- Control methods: physical, mechanical, chemical, biological

column1: - Rare tumor arising from the vidian nerve sheath, presenting with various symptoms like headaches, facial pain, decreased lacrimation, and nasal dryness, or as an incidental finding.

- Diagnosed through endoscopic biopsy and treated with surgical resection, stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), or stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT), depending on patient choice, functional status, and tumor characteristics.
- 49-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis (MS) incidentally found to have a schwannoma of the vidian canal on MRI.
- Asymptomatic, with the tumor originating within an expanded vidian canal and extending along the inferior margin of the right cavernous sinus.
- Treated with stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT) due to benign histology, MS background, and young age to minimize late normal tissue injury risks.

column2: • Aim: Compare stiffness of short-segment pedicle fixation using monoaxial or polyaxial screws with/without intermediate screw at fractured vertebra.
• Method: Twelve calf lumbar specimens (L1-L5) with unstable burst fracture at L3, divided into monoaxial (MPS) and polyaxial (PPS) screw groups, each with and without intermediate screw.
• Each specimen tested for flexion, extension, lateral bending, and axial rotation as intact, fractured, and fixed with 4- or 6-screw construct.
• Range of motion (ROM) recorded using Eagle-4 motion analysis system.
• Addition of intermediate screw decreased ROM in both MPS and PPS groups, indicating enhanced construct stability.
• MPS group with intermediate screw had significantly smaller ROM in all directions compared to standard short-segment construct.
• Short-segment construct with PPS had greater ROM in flexion and extension compared to MPS, but addition of intermediate screw increased stiffness significantly.
• **Method development**

column3: • Varying Cu and SCN concentrations to change crystal orientation
• Adding rb as structure-directing agent and sda removal

column2: • **Characterization**

column3: • X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns showing changes in crystallographic orientation
• Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images revealing morphology changes
• Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis showing increased surface area after rb removal

column2: • **Fluorescence quenching study**

column3: • Several dyes tested for fluorescence quenching on cuscn
• RB and FLTC showed strong quenching, indicating efficient hole transfer

column2: • **Photocathode performance**

column3: • RB-sensitized cuscn showed photocathodic behavior with methylviologen chloride electrolyte
• Porous cuscn electrode exhibited higher photocurrent and better rectification

column1: • Originates from communication between notochord and foregut
• Two main types: cystic (obstructed) and crust (non-obstructed)
- Cystic type can form abscesses or cysts
- Crust type forms crusts that shed periodically, causing halitosis and unpleasant taste
• Symptoms: space-occupying lesion (nasal obstruction, ear problems, dysphagia, cranial nerve paralysis) or rhinitis (choanal discharge, pharyngitis, laryngitis, bronchitis, gastritis)
• Incidence: approximately 4% in adults, peak between 15-30 years, no gender predilection
• Aim: Identify incidence, types, and clinical presentation of nasopharyngeal bursa disease over two years
• Method: Clinicoanatomical audit of patients diagnosed with nasopharyngeal bursitis, confirmed by endoscopic examination and imaging
• Six patients diagnosed (four males, two females, mean age 54)
• Incidence less than 1% of all rhinitis patients
• Two cystic types (classical and fibrosed) and three crust types identified
• Both types treated successfully with combined endoscopic nasal and transoral approach
• Presents with crust expectoration, retching, fetid postnasal discharge, and occipital pain
• Symptoms may have sudden onset and no recognized predisposing factors
• Histologically, shows reactive lymphoid mucosa with necrotic tissue
• Diagnosis: Endoscopic examination, CT/MRI for adhesion to cervical vertebrae
• Treatment: Endoscopic interruption of the bursa with electrocauterization at the base
• Differentiate from nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which lacks crust formation and specific symptoms

column2: + Increasing incidence over past few decades
+ Estimated 76,250 new cases in USA in 2012
+ Australia has one of the highest rates in the world
+ Melanoma can spread widely via lymphatic and blood vessels
+ Early diagnosis key factor for prognosis
+ Dermoscopy: non-invasive diagnostic technique for visualizing morphological features
+ Different techniques: solar scan, epiluminescence microscopy (ELM), cross-polarization ELM (CPL-ELM), side transillumination (TLM)
+ Dermoscopy enables better diagnosis than unaided eye
+ Important step in image analysis process

column2: + Aim: Evaluate characteristics and determinants of partial remission (PR) in type 1 diabetes and its long-term impact.
+ Design: Retrospective study of 242 children diagnosed with type 1 diabetes between 1994 and 2008, followed until adulthood.
+ Definition: Insulin-dose adjusted A1C (IDAA1C) ≤ 9%.
+ Occurrence: 56.2% of patients experienced PR, with no cases of complete remission.
+ Lower A1C at diagnosis: Girls entering PR had lower A1C than girls without PR (10.0% vs. 11.2%, p=0.028).
+ No diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) at diagnosis: Higher chances of PR (OR=0.43, p=0.018).
+ Higher C-peptide levels at diagnosis: Girls and boys entering PR had higher C-peptide levels than those without PR.
+ Mean duration: 9.2 months (range: 0.5-6.6 years).
+ Most patients (71.6%) experienced PR for less than 1 year, with 7.5% having PR for more than 2 years.

column2: + Lower A1C at 2 years in PR group (7.5% vs. 8.2%, p<0.0001).

column1: • **Impact of Partial Remission on Complications and Severe Hypoglycemia**

column2: + No long-term effects on diabetes complications or incidence of severe hypoglycemia.
+ Short-term effect on metabolic control in patients with PR durations between 510-570 days.

column1: - Aim: To evaluate whether levels of accurately quantified sedentary behavior and habitual physical activity could predict levels of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) and intrahepatic lipid (IHL) in adults with overweight/obesity.
- There would be a negative relationship between time spent in moderate intensity physical activity and levels of VAT and IHL.
- There would be a positive relationship between time spent in sedentary behavior and VAT and IHL content.
- Levels of sedentary behavior and moderate physical activity would explain a significant proportion of variance in VAT and IHL when modeled with known obesity-related health risk factors.

- Traditional risk factors (e.g., sex, age, waist circumference) were associated with VAT and IHL, but no relationship was observed between objectively measured physical inactivity and raised liver fat.
- A weak positive association was found between VAT volume and time spent in moderate activity, and total energy expenditure.

- Inclusion of objectively measured levels of moderate activity and sedentary behavior did not improve the potency of traditional risk factors for predicting the liver fat concentration or level of visceral adiposity.

column2: + Retrospective, observational, consecutive case series conducted in a tertiary eye care hospital in North India.
+ Included patients with fireworks-related injuries during Diwali festival (2 days before, day of, and 2 days after) for 5 consecutive years (2011-2015).
+ Total of 53 eyes of 45 patients were seen, with males being the majority.
+ Most injuries were closed-globe (90.56%), with 5 eyes having open-globe injuries.
+ 33.96% of eyes underwent surgical management, while 64.15% were managed conservatively.
+ Final BCVA was 6/6 in 22 eyes, and 1 eye had no perception of light.
+ 5 eyes developed phthisis bulbi, with 3 undergoing secondary enucleation.
+ SCH is common, affecting 4-20% of adults, with higher prevalence in women, elderly, and iodine-sufficient populations.

column2: + Treatment of SCH is typically considered for pregnant women, infertile individuals, those with associated symptoms, or high risk of progression to overt hypothyroidism.
+ The benefits and risks of SCH treatment remain controversial, with some studies showing improvements in cardiovascular function and lipid levels, while others found no significant effects.

+ The TRUST study, a large-scale, randomized controlled trial, is currently underway to assess the effects of thyroid hormone replacement in older adults with persistent SCH and provide definitive answers.
+ Aim: Investigate clinical history and treatment need for patients with gdh-positive, toxin-negative stool specimens.
+ Design: Retrospective study of patients (age ≥2 years) who submitted stool specimens for CDAD diagnosis using EIA between March 2013 and June 2014.

+ Three groups based on EIA results: toxin-positive stool (positive stool group), toxin-negative stool/toxin-positive isolate (discrepant negative/positive group), and dual toxin-negative stool and isolate (dual negative group).
+ No significant differences in clinical characteristics among groups.
+ Significant difference in diarrhea duration: positive stool group (10.6 days) > discrepant negative/positive group (7.9 days) > dual negative group (3.4 days).
+ Significantly fewer patients in the discrepant negative/positive group received CDAD treatment compared to the positive stool group.
+ Shorter symptom duration in toxin-negative patients despite lack of CDAD drug treatment.
+ Diarrhea duration tended to be shorter in patients with toxin-negative stool specimens but toxin-positive isolates.
+ EIA has lower sensitivity but higher positive predictive value for toxin detection compared to PCR.
+ EIA directly measures toxin proteins, reflecting the patient's actual disease status.
+ Retrospective design, small sample size, and absence of molecular biological testing.
+ Potential differences in toxin production-related gene sequences between patient groups were not investigated.
+ Patients with toxin-negative stool specimens but toxin-positive isolates may still require infection prevention measures.
+ Shorter diarrhea duration in toxin-negative patients suggests limited need for CDAD treatment.
+ Nucleic acid amplification tests, like PCR, do not evaluate toxin production.
+ *Large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial*

column1: • Rare genodermatosis characterized by adnexal skin tumors in scalp and face.
• Due to mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CYLD on chromosome 16q12q13.
• Low risk of malignancy, requires long-term follow-up.
• 71-year-old woman with progressive development of asymptomatic lesions in her head over 4 years.
• Multiple rounded skin-colored or erythematous papules, 28 mm in diameter, located in scalp and forehead.
• Excisional biopsies revealed spiradenomas and one cylindroma.
• Family history positive for similar lesions in mother, maternal uncle, and two daughters.
• CYLD gene sequencing revealed heterozygous mutation c.1628_1629delct in the patient and her two affected daughters.
• Unaffected daughter and children tested negative.
• Progressive development of adnexal skin tumors in scalp and face, starting from puberty.
• Higher incidence in females, no racial distinction.
• Associated with increased risk of salivary glands neoplasms and other tumors.
• Cylindromas appear mainly on the scalp, spiradenomas on extremities, trunk, and less frequently on the scalp.
• Tumor suppressor gene encoding a deubiquitinating enzyme.
• Negatively regulates factors involved in inflammation and cellular division.
• Germline mutations predispose to BSS, sometimes with a second acquired somatic mutation.
• Excisional biopsies for diagnosis and removal of tumors.
• Long-term follow-up due to low risk of malignancy.

column2: + • Local tissue RAAS plays significant roles in cardiovascular diseases
+ • Aldosterone and mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) activation cause structural and electrical remodeling, fibrosis, oxidative stress, inflammation, and arrhythmias in the heart
+ • MR antagonists, such as eplerenone, have shown beneficial effects in patients with heart failure
+ • RAAS inhibitors, like ACEi and ARBs, protect against hypertension and/or diabetes-induced end-organ damage but do not completely prevent it
+ • Aldosterone escape phenomenon occurs in up to 40% of patients with heart failure, necessitating additional RAAS inhibition
+ • Combination therapies of ACEi, ARBs, and MR antagonists have shown promise in reducing mortality in patients with severe congestive heart failure and left ventricular dysfunction after MI

+ • Method: Isolated rat hearts were subjected to 30 min of global ischemia followed by 30 min of reperfusion, with drugs administered for 30 min before or after ischemia

column1: • **Cardiovascular Disease and N-3 Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids (N-3 PUFAs)**

• Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of mortality, with ongoing research focusing on preventing early development of risk factors like atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance.

• N-3 PUFAs, particularly eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), have cardioprotective effects, including lipid-lowering, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, and antiarrhythmogenic properties.

• Low-grade chronic inflammation is a prominent process in CVD development, with N-3 PUFAs modulating inflammatory response and reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines and markers like C-reactive protein (CRP).
• N-3 PUFAs are essential fatty acids, with EPA and DHA primarily derived from dietary sources, while alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) is a plant-based precursor with limited conversion to EPA and DHA.
• Epidemiological evidence and randomized controlled trials support the cardioprotective effects of fish oil-derived EPA and DHA, with modest intake reducing the risk of coronary heart disease (CHD).

• EPA and DHA have pleiotropic effects on cardiovascular health, influencing membrane fluidity, permeability, and the activity of transmembrane proteins, including receptors, enzymes, and ion channels.

• DHA, rather than EPA, is preferentially incorporated into myocardial cell membranes, contributing to its antiarrhythmic and heart rate-lowering effects, as well as its hypotensive and anti-inflammatory actions.

• N-3 PUFAs, especially EPA and DHA, reduce triglyceride (TG) levels, with long-term intake also increasing LDL cholesterol and HDL cholesterol, mainly due to larger, potentially less atherogenic LDL particles.

• Hypertension and dyslipidemia are important risk factors for CVD, with modifications of erythrocyte membrane fatty acid composition being early indicators of lipid metabolism pathology and ah pathogenesis.

• N-3 PUFAs improve endothelial function, reduce markers of endothelial dysfunction, and enhance the stability of atherosclerotic plaques, potentially explaining reductions in nonfatal and fatal cardiovascular events.
• **Pioneering Pathologists and H. pylori's Role in Gastric Cancer**

column2: + • **Rudolf Virchow's Inflammation Theory**

column3: - Cancer arises from normal cells in response to chronic irritation or inflammation
- Many gastrointestinal and hepatobiliary malignancies are inflammation-induced

column2: + • **Pelayo Correa's Cascade Model**

column3: - Chronic atrophic gastritis progresses to intestinal metaplasia and cancer over 30-50 years
- Initial changes occur in the first decade of life, coinciding with H. pylori colonization

column2: + • **Robin Warren and Barry Marshall's Discovery of H. pylori**

column3: - H. pylori causes gastritis and peptic ulcer disease
- Warren and Marshall speculated about H. pylori's role in gastric cancer

column1: • **Evidence for H. pylori's Role in Gastric Cancer**

column2: + • **Early Studies**

column3: - Cross-sectional studies provided weak evidence for H. pylori's role
- Clinicopathologic studies yielded inconsistent results

column2: + • **Convincing Evidence from Cohort Studies**

column3: - Three large cohorts with nested case-control studies showed a significant association between H. pylori infection and gastric cancer
- World Health Organization classified H. pylori as a definite carcinogen in 1994

column2: + • **Cardia Cancers**

column3: - Not strongly associated with H. pylori infection
- Arise via alternative mechanisms with risk factors similar to cancers of the gastroesophageal junction and lower esophagus

column2: + • **Intestinal vs Diffuse Subtypes**

column3: - H. pylori is a risk factor for both intestinal and diffuse gastric cancer subtypes
- CagA-positive strains increase the risk of gastric cancer more than CagA-negative strains

column3: - Uemura et al showed that H. pylori-infected patients had a higher rate of progression to gastric cancer
- Prospective interventional studies were needed to prove H. pylori's role

column2: + • **Meta-Analyses of Eradication Studies**

column3: - H. pylori eradication decreases the risk of gastric cancer development by approximately 40% in primary prevention and 54% in tertiary prevention
- Benefit is most evident in areas",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"

column2: • Aim: Compare functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab vs. ranibizumab in Turkish patients with neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD) on an as-needed treatment regimen.
• Design: Retrospective study of patients treated between 2009 and 2011, with a minimum follow-up of 12 months.
• Inclusion criteria: Age ≥50, newly diagnosed nAMD, no treatments other than bevacizumab or ranibizumab alone, minimum follow-up of 12 months.
• Exclusion criteria: Other retinal diseases, previous intravitreal injections, history of photodynamic therapy or laser photocoagulation.
• All patients received monthly doses of bevacizumab (1.25 mg/0.05 mL) or ranibizumab (0.5 mg/0.05 mL) for the first three months.
• Patients were then examined monthly and retreated if specific criteria were met (visual loss, macular hemorrhage, CNV enlargement, persistent subretinal fluid).
• Best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central retinal thickness (CRT) were measured at baseline, months 3, 6, 9, 12, and at the most recent follow-up.
• Changes in BCVA and CRT over time were analyzed using paired sample t-test.
• Both bevacizumab and ranibizumab groups showed significant improvement in BCVA and CRT compared to baseline at every time point.
• No statistically significant difference was found between the two groups in terms of change in BCVA, CRT, injection numbers, or complications.
• 86.1% of bevacizumab and 86.5% of ranibizumab patients had stable or improved visual acuity after a mean follow-up of approximately 18 months.
+ Evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with preeclampsia (PE)
+ Assess the predictive value of hypoproteinemia (low albumin levels) in PE
+ Retrospective cohort study
+ 299 women with singleton pregnancies, January 2014 - June 2015
+ Maternal and Child Health Hospital of Anhui Province, China
+ 220 with mild hypoproteinemia (MHP, albumin ≥25 g/L)
+ 79 with severe hypoproteinemia (SHP, albumin <25 g/L)
+ Singleton pregnancies
+ Preeclampsia diagnosis according to ISSHP guidelines
+ Kidney diseases, preexisting proteinuria, essential hypertension, other maternal chronic conditions, twin pregnancies
+ Maternal: delivery mode, eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, hypertension, abnormal liver/renal function, ascites, oligohydramnios, thrombocytopenia, abruptio placenta
+ Neonatal: perinatal deaths, preterm birth, neonatal asphyxia, fetal growth restriction (FGR), birth weight
+ SHP group delivered earlier, had higher CS rate, and more severe maternal complications
+ Neonates in SHP group had lower birth weight, higher FGR, NICU admission, and preterm delivery rates
+ SHP was a significant risk factor for CS, poor maternal, and neonatal outcomes
+ Severe hypoproteinemia in PE is associated with worse maternal and neonatal outcomes
+ Closer surveillance is warranted for women with SHP PE

column2: + • Pre-elimination program since 2009
+ • P. vivax is the predominant species
+ • Active case detection and timely treatment implemented
+ • Bagh-e Malek region in Minab district, Hormozgan province
+ • Low transmission area with 15 cases in 2011
+ • Predominant species: P. vivax
+ • Cross-sectional survey with 200 healthy volunteers
+ • Three diagnostic methods used: microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR
+ • Follow-up samples collected 30 and 60 days after initial sampling
+ • No parasites detected in any sample
+ • No malaria parasites detected during 60-day follow-up
+ • All samples remained symptomless
+ • No positive results for P. falciparum or non-falciparum species
+ • No asymptomatic malaria infections detected
+ • No mixed infections or sub-clinical parasitaemia identified
+ • Three P. vivax positive samples (1.5%) detected
+ • All positive cases were female, one with a malaria history
+ • No P. falciparum infections detected
+ • Molecular methods (e.g., nested-PCR) important for detecting asymptomatic carriers
+ • Microscopy and RDTs should be used alongside molecular methods for active case surveillance
+ • All three methods (microscopy, RDT, and molecular) should be used to improve sensitivity, specificity, and reliability

+ **Immunotherapy Approaches**: Many new immunotherapy approaches have been developed for cancer treatment, including infusional cytokine therapies, intravesical BCG therapy, and active cellular therapy targeting prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP).

+ **Biomarkers for Immune Response**: Identifying biomarkers of immune response is crucial for evaluating the efficacy of immunotherapy. For antigen-specific vaccines, immune responses to the target antigen can be used as a biomarker. However, for broadly active immune modulating agents like T-cell checkpoint inhibitors, appropriate biomarkers have been more elusive.

+ **Machine Learning and Bayesian Belief Networks (BBNs)**: The authors used machine learning and BBNs to identify promising biomarkers and potential biomarker networks in their study. They trained several BBNs to identify promising biomarkers and then used these networks to select a subset of features to train a network of immune biomarkers as they related to observed declines in serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA).

+ **Study Findings**: The authors found that IgG immune responses could be detected to individual antigens and were associated with specific treatments. They also found that predictive models might be developed with diagnostic potential using IgG responses to groups of antigens at three months. The use of IgG responses to panels of tissue-associated antigens as measures of antigen spread was suggested as a potential biomarker of immunological efficacy for immune-active therapies.

• Study conducted in the department of oral medicine and radiology and a cancer centre.
• Total sample of 90 individuals: 60 oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) patients and 30 healthy controls.
• OSCC patients were between 25 and 75 years, with histologically proven oral cancer but before treatment.
• Healthy volunteers were aged 25-75, with no history of tobacco or alcohol consumption and no systemic illnesses.
• Serum L-fucose level was estimated using a clinical chemistry autoanalyzer based on the Winzler method.
• Statistical analysis used: Independent samples t-test for two groups, one-way ANOVA for three or more groups.
• Mean serum L-fucose level in OSCC patients was 10.85 mg/dL, and in healthy controls, it was 3.47 mg/dL, with a significant difference (p < 0.001).
• L-fucose levels progressively increased with the stage of oral cancer (p < 0.001).
• No significant correlation found between L-fucose levels and histopathological grading, gender, or age.
• L-fucose is a monosaccharide involved in cell-to-cell communication and signaling pathways.
• Increased fucosylation is associated with elevated fucosidase activity and poor prognosis in cancer patients.
• Serum L-fucose levels could be a promising approach for early detection, diagnosis, and prognosis of various cancer types, including oral carcinoma.
• Serum L-fucose level is not specific to oral cancer and can be elevated in other pathological states and malignancies.
• Further investigation on a large scale is needed to confirm the effectiveness of serum L-fucose as a tumor marker in oral cancer diagnosis and management.
* **Lcn2-deficient mice exhibit increased body weight and adiposity:**

column2: + Gain more body weight when fed a high-fat diet (HFD) or aged
+ Increased body fat mass and enlarged organs, particularly the liver
+ No significant differences in metabolic phenotypes when fed a regular chow diet (RCD) at a young age

column1: * **Lcn2 mice display cold sensitivity and lower body temperature:**

column2: + Fail to maintain body temperature when acutely exposed to cold (4°C)
+ Lower rectal temperature in female mice and a trend toward decrease in male mice at 22°C
+ Cold exposure stimulates lcn2 expression in white adipose tissue (WAT)

column1: * **Lcn2 regulates adaptive thermogenesis and mitochondrial function:**

column2: + Impaired adaptive thermogenesis in lcn2 mice
+ Decreased mitochondrial oxidative capacity in brown adipose tissue (BAT) and skeletal muscle
+ Downregulated expression of mitochondrial genes and thermogenic regulators in BAT and muscle

column1: * **Lcn2 deficiency leads to insulin resistance and glucose intolerance:**

column2: + More glucose intolerant and insulin resistant upon HFD feeding
+ Impaired insulin signaling in liver, muscle, and adipose tissue
+ Increased hepatic glucose production and fatty liver disease
+ Higher serum levels of triglycerides, cholesterol, and free fatty acids in RCD-fed lcn2 mice
+ Increased triglycerides synthesis and decreased VLDL secretion in HFD-fed lcn2 mice
+ Increased inflammatory state in lcn2 mice, with upregulated proinflammatory cytokines and downregulated anti-inflammatory markers

column1: * **Study on Rat Model for Non-Traumatic Osteonecrosis of the Femoral Head**
* Rats were given LPS and methylprednisolone injections to promote non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH).
* Hindlimb unloading was employed to prevent weight bearing on the hindlimbs.
* Femoral head osteonecrosis was observed in 63.6% of weight-bearing (WB) rats and 54.5% of non-weight-bearing (NWB) rats, with no significant difference between groups.
* Histopathological examination showed similar findings in both WB and NWB groups, with empty lacunae and bone marrow cell necrosis.
* No osteonecrosis was observed in the humeral head of either WB or NWB rats.
* NWB rats had a larger number of hematopoietic cells and fewer fat cells compared to WB rats.
* Weight bearing does not contribute to the initial development of osteonecrosis in rats.
* The rat model may help in understanding the pathogenesis of osteonecrosis but may not be suitable for observing femoral head collapse mechanisms.

column2: + Aim: To determine the frequency of UTI causative organisms in neonates at Bahrami Children's Hospital over 8 years.
+ Design: Retrospective case series using non-random sampling.
+ Neonates admitted to the neonatal division of Bahrami Children's Hospital, Tehran, Iran, from June 2004 to June 2012.
+ Total cases: 73 (mean age: 14.14 days, mean birth weight: 3055.85 grams, mean admission weight: 3180.55 grams).
+ Boys: 69.9% (51 neonates), Girls: 30.1% (22 neonates), Boys-to-Girls ratio: 2.32.
+ Four different bacteria isolated: E. coli, Enterobacter, Klebsiella, and S. epidermidis.
+ Most prevalent organism: E. coli (64.4%, 47 cases).
+ Other isolated organisms and their frequencies: Enterobacter (19.2%, 14 cases), Klebsiella (4.1%, 3 cases), S. epidermidis (2.7%, 2 cases).
+ E. coli:

column3: - Most resistant to: Ampicillin (93.6%), Cefixime (85.7%), Cephalexin (77.3%).
- Most susceptible to: Norfloxacin (100%), Ciprofloxacin (100%), Cefotaxime (63.6%).

column2: + Enterobacter:

column3: - Most resistant to: Amikacin (100%), Ampicillin (92.8%).
- Most susceptible to: Ceftazidime (100%), Norfloxacin (100%), Ceftizoxime (71.4%).

column2: + Klebsiella and S. epidermidis:

column3: - Both completely resistant to Ampicillin (100%).
- Klebsiella: Resistant to most antibiotics, sensitive to Gentamycin (50%).
- S. epidermidis: Sensitive to Gentamycin (100%).

- Classical simple virilizing (SV) form: 8 patients, diagnosed between birth and 6 years, treated with hydrocortisone
- Non-classical (NC) form: 8 patients (women only), diagnosed between 15 and 44 years, treated with hydrocortisone or dexamethasone

- 1 patient (classic SV) showed moderate right temporal lobe atrophy
- 2 patients (NC) had hippocampal atrophy and dysgenesis
- Mental retardation in 3 patients (moderate in 2, profound in 1)
- 16 patients (61.5%) had poor hormonal control due to non-compliance

column1: • Aim: To evaluate the role of urethral plate characters in the success of Snodgrass tip urethroplasty for primary anterior penile hypospadias.
• Method: Retrospective study of 100 children (Jan 2010 - Dec 2013) who underwent Snodgrass tip repair at Mayo Hospital, Hodeidah, Yemen.
• Width: Group A (>8 mm), Group B (<8 mm)
• Narrow urethral plate (<8 mm) associated with higher fistula rate and failed 8Fr calibration.
• Flat urethral plate had higher fistula rate and failed 8Fr calibration, but not statistically significant.
• Tip urethroplasty has good cosmetic and functional results.
• Flat and narrow urethral plates may benefit from augmentation with buccal mucosal graft.

column1: * **Study on Trichomonas Vaginalis Infection in Peru**

column2: + *Prevalence and Risk Factors*

column3: - Prevalence of T. vaginalis infection was 16.2% among socially marginalized women in coastal Peru.
- Older age, lower education, single status, unprotected sex with non-steady partners, and multiple sex partners were associated with higher prevalence.
- No association found between vaginal symptoms and T. vaginalis infection.

column2: + *Implications and Recommendations*

column3: - Long-term prevalent infections in older women may be missed by screening programs focused on younger age groups.
- Syndromic management may result in both over and under treatment of T. vaginalis infection.
- Screening and treatment programs are needed to control the spread of infection, and partner treatment should also be prioritized.
- Improved disease control activities are needed to reduce adverse reproductive health outcomes associated with trichomoniasis.
- Further studies are required to determine if screening and treatment of trichomoniasis will improve reproductive health and birth outcomes.
- T. vaginalis is widely prevalent and easily treatable, making it a target for public health interventions.

column2: + *Definition and Characteristics*

column3: - A severe form of epilepsy in children, classified as a symptomatic generalized epilepsy syndrome
- Characterized by multiple seizure types, including tonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures
- Interictal EEG pattern shows slow spike wave discharges and paroxysms of low voltage fast activity during sleep
- Associated with cognitive impairment and behavioral disorders

column2: * **Treatment and Prognosis**

column3: - Poor prognosis due to both seizures and cognitive outcome
- Difficult to treat due to multiple seizure types and encephalopathic nature
- Valproic acid is the first-line medication, followed by second-line agents like lamotrigine, rufinamide, topiramate, clobazam, felbamate, and levetiracetam
- Rufinamide, a novel anticonvulsant, has shown promise in treating LGS seizures with a good safety profile and minimal side effects
